title: Dem Claim That Trump Tariffs Would Cause Prices To ‘Soar’ Crumbles Due To Positive Economic News
content: A recent Democratic ad campaign claiming President Donald Trump’s tariffs have caused prices to “soar” is undercut by recent data ...
resumen: A Democratic ad campaign claimed President Donald Trump’s tariffs have caused prices to “soar”. House Majority Forward (HMF), the nonprofit arm of a House Democratic leadership-aligned super PAC, announced a series of ads Wednesday targeting 26 House Republicans for supporting the president’s tariffs, which HMF claims has caused prices to skyrocket. Several markers of inflation fell to four-year-lows in April while Americans’ wages are rising faster than the rate of inflation. The personal consumption expenditures (PCE) price index slowed to 2.1% in April, an increase of just 0.1% for the month, the lowest rate since February 2021. The consumer price index slowed to just 2.3% year-over-year and 0.2% month-over-month in April, the slowest rate in more than four years. Personal incomes also rose 0.8% for the month, nearly tripling expectations, according to the Commerce Department. In April grocery prices saw their biggest drop in five years since September 2020, largely driven by a sharp decline in the price of eggs, which fell to their lowest price in roughly 40 years. U.S. consumer confidence also surged in May, reversing five straight months of decline, according to a report from the The Conference Board. EJ Antoni, chief economist at the Heritage Foundation, stated that the claim that prices are soaring is empirically false by any measure. NRCC Spokesman Mike Marinella stated that prices continue to fall, and the economy is booming under President Trump and Republicans in Congress. Antoni cautioned that persistent high tariffs coupled with a trade war with China could “significantly raise prices” but that scenario has not yet happened. House Democrats claimed that Congressional Republicans’ reforms to Medicaid in the president’s sweeping tax and spending bill would kick 13.7 million Americans off of the entitlement program’s rolls. The New York Times fact-checked the claim as “an exaggeration.” Democrats added in roughly four million additional people who are expected to lose Medicaid coverage due to the expiration of a policy unrelated to the “big, beautiful bill.” The House-drafted proposal would kick off 1.4 million illegal migrants who receive coverage through state Medicaid programs. Nearly 5 million Americans are also slated to lose coverage rather than meet requirements for certain able-bodied, childless adults to work or volunteer at least 20 hours a week. HMF was also caught paying for billboards in March alleging that certain House Republicans had voted to cut Medicaid despite the bill’s text not mentioning the entitlement program nor prescribing any specific policy directions. Several of the billboards were taken down after House Republicans’ campaign arm sent a cease-and-desist letter to the vendor responsible for putting up the billboards.

title: The most important economic reform
content: What’s the most important economic reform that President Ferdinand “Bongbong” Marcos, Jr. can do at this stage? Is it to amend the restrictive economic provisions in the Constitution? Is it to ...
resumen:
The most important economic reform that President Ferdinand “Bongbong” Marcos, Jr. can do is to reverse the strong peso and undervalue the currency. Weakening the peso will stimulate exports, protect local industries, increase incomes of Overseas Filipino Worker (OFW) families, and make the Philippines more attractive to foreign investments.

The balance of trade worsened, with imports exceeding exports and ballooning to $52 billion in 2024. A weak peso will benefit agriculture, stimulate agricultural exports, and protect farmers. The government should abolish quantitative restrictions and use the weak peso to protect local farmers. A weak peso will also be good for the tourism and mining industries and act as an economic stimulus for OFW families. It will also shield the Philippines from cheap Chinese goods.

The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas’ (BSP) studies show that the pass-through rate of a depreciated currency to inflation is small. A weak peso is the strongest incentive for foreign investors. A strong peso will undercut tariff advantages and negate benefits under Free Trade Agreements.

To reverse the strong peso, the BSP can cut interest rates and buy dollars to weaken the peso and build up its reserves. The BSP can always sterilize the increased pesos by floating its bonds.

The BSP’s studies show that the pass-through rate, or the rise in inflation due to depreciation, is insignificant. The incomes of domestic players — OFWs, exporters, local industries, and BPOs, will rise and compensate for any one-time blip in oil prices. If the BSP won’t listen, Congress should pass a law amending the BSP Charter to make balancing price stability with growth and full employment as BSP’s primary objective. The Philippines should even consider scrapping the regime of free capital movement and adopting a semi-fixed exchange rate and soft capital controls.

China devalued the yuan by 21% in 1989, 17% from 1990 to 1993, and 33% in 1994. Vietnam depreciated its currency by 43.6% between 2002 and 2016. Vietnam experienced export growth of more than 10% per annum compared to the Philippines’ paltry export growth of 3% per annum during the same period. Vietnam doubled its export-to-GDP ratio from 40% in 1999 to 87% in 2023 and became the sixth biggest trading partner of the US. The Philippines posted an export-to-GDP ratio of 28% in 2023. Vietnam’s FDI reached $38 billion in 2024 compared to the Philippines’ FDI at $8.9 billion in 2024.

In 1946, the US forced the Philippines to adopt a P2 to $1 exchange rate. In 1949, the Philippines experienced a foreign exchange crisis. Japan’s exchange rate was ¥3.50 to $1 before the war, ¥50 to $1 in 1946 and ¥360 in 1949. Japan’s lost decades can be traced directly to the Plaza Accord.

A weak peso is a net plus for government revenues. Weakening or undervaluing the peso is the most important, most effective, fastest, and easiest to implement economic reform.

Calixto V. Chikiamco is a member of the board of IDEA (Institute for Development and Econometric Analysis).

title: Aus mulls taking Trump tariffs to world trade umpire
content: Australia is mulling taking a case against Donald Trump's tariffs on steel and aluminium and goods imports to the global trade umpire.
resumen:
El 29 de mayo de 2024, el Consejo de Ministros aprobó el proyecto de Ley de Eficiencia del Sector Público, que busca mejorar la gestión y el funcionamiento de las administraciones públicas. La ley se estructura en tres títulos:

*   **Título I: Eficiencia Organizativa.** Introduce medidas para simplificar la estructura administrativa, reducir cargas burocráticas y mejorar la coordinación entre las diferentes administraciones.
*   **Título II: Eficiencia en la Gestión de los Recursos Humanos.** Se enfoca en la optimización de la plantilla, la formación de los empleados públicos y la promoción de la igualdad y la conciliación.
*   **Título III: Eficiencia en la Gestión Económico-Financiera.** Contempla medidas para mejorar la planificación presupuestaria, la gestión de los contratos públicos y el control del gasto.

El proyecto de ley incluye la creación de la Oficina Nacional de Evaluación, que se encargará de evaluar el impacto de las políticas públicas y proponer mejoras. También se prevé la creación de un registro de altos cargos y directivos del sector público, con el objetivo de aumentar la transparencia y la rendición de cuentas.

President Trump's tariff policies have brought uncertainty to the stock market. The S&P 500, Nasdaq Composite, and Dow Jones Industrial Average experienced double-digit declines after the April 2 announcement, but rebounded. Tariffs are a tax on imported or exported goods, used to negotiate trade deals and encourage domestic manufacturing. Economists worry about the cost of increased manufacturing investment in the U.S., potentially leading to inflation.

Two companies that could emerge as winners are:

1.  **Home Depot (NYSE: HD)**: The home improvement industry in the U.S. is essentially a duopoly between Home Depot and Lowe's. Home Depot sources more than half of its inventory from domestic vendors.
2.  **Nucor**: Higher prices for imported steel from other countries, particularly China, should benefit Nucor. Companies across different sectors have committed to increased domestic manufacturing, including Project Stargate, a $500 billion vision for more artificial intelligence infrastructure in the U.S.

title: EU threatens countermeasures over Trump's steel tariffs hike
content: The European Commission said on Saturday that Europe was prepared to retaliate against President Donald Trump’s plan to double tariffs on imported steel and aluminum, raising the prospect of an ...
resumen: The European Commission said on Saturday that Europe was prepared to retaliate against President Donald Trump’s plan to double tariffs on imported steel and aluminum. Trump announced on Friday that he would increase tariffs on imported steel and aluminum to 50 percent from 25 percent. The European Commission said it "strongly" regrets Trump's plan to increase tariffs and that the EU is prepared to impose countermeasures. The EU had paused its countermeasures to create space for continued negotiations. If no mutually acceptable solution is reached, both existing and additional EU measures will automatically take effect on 14 July — or earlier, if circumstances require. Trump said the increased tariff would also apply to aluminum products and that it would take effect on Wednesday. The US is the world's largest steel importer, excluding the EU, with a total of 26.2 million tonnes of imported steel in 2024, according to the Department of Commerce.

title: A North American customs union may help ease trade issues
content: In an attempt to escape the U.S.-China trade war, many Chinese companies and affiliates have moved production or set up satellite production in Mexico in cities such as Juarez and Tijuana. This is ...
resumen:
The U.S.-China trade war resulted in a lowering of U.S. tariffs of 145 percent on Chinese imports to 30 percent, and a lowering of 125 percent tariffs on U.S. imports into China to 10 percent. A truce was declared for 90 days as negotiations take place.

Chinese companies have moved production or set up satellite production in Mexico to avoid U.S. import tariffs and benefit from reduced or zero tariffs under the U.S-Mexico-Canada-Agreement (USMCA).

The Trump Administration has threatened tariffs on Chinese companies producing in Mexico and shipping their products to the U.S.

A possible solution could involve a modified version of a customs union, where USMCA members Mexico, Canada, and the U.S. lower tariffs among themselves and develop a unified common external tariff on imports from non-member countries.

A twist on a North American customs union could be a common policy among members on foreign investment, in this case from China, in either of the three USMCA countries.

Mexico, Canada, and the U.S. could also develop a policy applying special tariffs on Chinese companies in North America.

The USMCA is up for review in 2026.

The formation of a customs union would take trust and goodwill among the three North American partners.

Jerry Pacheco is President of the Border Industrial Association.

title: (EDITORIAL from Korea Times on June 2)
content: Erratic tariff strategy Policy inconsistency fuels trade instability: Korea must remain strategic. The trade landscape between the United States and its partners has once again be ...
resumen: The trade landscape between the United States and its partners has been thrown into confusion. A recent ruling by the U.S. Court of International Trade invalidated President Donald Trump's reciprocal tariffs, finding they exceeded the authority granted to the executive branch under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA). The U.S. Court of Appeals temporarily reinstated the tariffs, granting the Trump administration continued leeway until the appeals process concludes. The administration would pursue the matter all the way to the U.S. Supreme Court. This legal tug-of-war reveals deeper systemic issues in Trump's trade policy: unpredictability, legal overreach and the weaponization of tariffs for political gain. These features have destabilized global supply chains and eroded America's credibility as a reliable economic partner. For countries like Korea, this inconsistency poses significant strategic and economic challenges. Trump's approach to trade has been characterized by an "America First" mantra that treats economic relationships as zero-sum games. The use of tariffs as bargaining chips has made it nearly impossible for allies and adversaries alike to plan and respond with confidence. The Trump administration repeatedly threatened steep tariffs on key exports such as cars and steel, only to later renegotiate under duress or delay enforcement for strategic timing. Trump's reliance on dubious legal justifications further compounds the issue. IEEPA, intended for genuine national emergencies, was stretched beyond reasonable limits to support trade objectives. The initial court ruling noted that trade deficits do not constitute national emergencies and that the executive branch cannot bypass congressional authority over commerce. The Trump administration's attempt to circumvent these checks through legal gymnastics not only undermines domestic institutional integrity but also alienates close allies. Trump's allies have signaled they are prepared to continue pressing forward through legal loopholes. White House National Economic Council director Kevin Hassett publicly stated there are "three or four other methods" to impose tariffs if courts block the current path. For Korea, such erratic policymaking creates an environment of constant uncertainty. Korea must avoid being reactive. Korea should focus on reinforcing its strategic position through three core actions: strengthen the competitiveness of its key export industries, accelerate export market diversification, and deepen multilateral and regional partnerships and assert its interests through global trade institutions such as the World Trade Organization. Trump must rethink his approach. Lasting influence comes not from coercion but from consistency, respect for international rules and adherence to domestic legal boundaries. He should pursue long-term competitiveness through investment in innovation, workforce development and infrastructure. The U.S. president must acknowledge that alienating economic partners through threats and unilateralism weakens, not strengthens, American leadership. If Trump's trade policy is to be taken seriously on the global stage, it must evolve from a tool of bluster to an engine of stable, mutual prosperity. The international community must brace for renewed volatility. Korea, by investing in its capabilities and anchoring its diplomacy in strategy rather than reaction, can chart a course through this turbulence with resilience and clarity.

title: Can Pakistan leverage US food imports?
content: TRADE POLICIES Trump's tariff plan has sent shockwaves around the world. The WTO warns of a 0.2 per cent shrinkage of global trade, as opposed to a growth forecast of 2.7 per cent before the new ...
resumen:
Trump's tariff plan has sent shockwaves around the world. The WTO warns of a 0.2 per cent shrinkage of global trade, as opposed to a growth forecast of 2.7 per cent before the new tariff policy.

Pakistan is moving towards trade liberalisation. Pakistan has opted to propose a zero-tariff bilateral trade agreement with Washington and introduced a National Trade Policy 2025-30, which aims to liberalise trade by lowering the maximum customs duty (CD) to 15 per cent and eliminating additional customs duties (ACD) and regulatory duties (RD).

The US is a major export destination for Pakistani goods and Pakistan lacks the economic prowess to sustain a $564 million export loss.

Negotiatory policy responses are critical to mitigating the 29 per cent tariff imposed by the U.S. in retaliation for Pakistan’s $3 billion trade surplus, which would cost Pakistan only approximately $85 million in tariff revenue.

Pakistan is a severely food insecure country with 20.7 per cent of the population suffering from malnutrition, 40 per cent of children under 5 suffering from stunting, and the economy losing 3.0 per cent of GDP to malnutrition.

Pakistan is the 28th largest export market for US foods and agricultural-related products. The top food imports from the US consist of tree nuts, pulses and processed foods. Pakistan imposes high tariffs and additional regulatory duties on these products, except for pulses.

Imported items are not included in an average Pakistani's diet.

Lowered prices and increased quantity due to trade liberalisation policies would not add any value to Pakistan’s food landscape, and a lower price would only impact the already affluent people, for whom the cost of a healthy diet is already affordable.

Trade liberalisation would entail easy and affordable access of processed foods into Pakistani market and can threaten the acceleration of ‘nutrition transition’.

Pakistan should opt for a multidimensional approach by exploring various strategies to strengthen the country’s economic position in the global arena and combat food insecurity.

Pakistan Pure Food Laws (PFL) regulates processed foods but these regulations mostly deal with additives and food preservatives. The Government should also work towards limiting the excessive use of problematic nutrients like trans fats, sodium and sugar in processed foods.

Labelling is an effective tool, as it provides consumers with the instant knowledge needed to make informed purchases. Labelling should be harmonised to ensure smooth and healthy trade.

Pulses are a staple in the Pakistani diet across all socio-economic backgrounds. Pakistan's pulse consumption far exceeds its domestic production. The import of pulses has already increased 12.95 per cent compared to the previous fiscal year.

A zero-tariff agreement on the table would make Pakistan's pulse market more inviting to US exporters.

Pakistan would become vulnerable to external shocks such as geopolitical tensions (Ukraine-Russia war, Pakistan-India tensions, etc), climate change-induced supply disruptions, or shifts in US trade policy.

Food imports also risk pushing local businesses out and taking over the market.

Trade liberalisation threatens the dumping of GMO crops in Pakistan.

NTBs can be used to restrict the dumping of GMO crops in Pakistan. Pakistan has an extensive set of SOPs in place for importing GMOs. Pakistan needs to implement biosafety NTBs, like mandatory labelling if GMO content is greater than 0.9 per cent. The government should work towards introducing quotas on the import of GMO soya bean.

Pakistan should opt for a multidimensional approach by exploring various strategies -- including tariff negotiation, trade diversification, the promotion of value-added products and investment in local processing industries -- to strengthen Pakistan’s economic position in the global arena and combat food insecurity.

title: The latest on Trump’s tariffs and his massive domestic policy bill
content: More uncertainty surrounds President Donald Trump’s tariffs as a new week begins. Meanwhile, the White House is ramping up its halting efforts to secure ceasefires in Gaza and Ukraine. Follow for live ...
resumen:
**June 1, 2025: Donald Trump presidency news**

*   **Trade war:** President Donald Trump’s tariffs “are not going away,” his commerce secretary said Sunday, despite a legal battle over the president’s use of emergency powers to implement them. Trade tensions appear to be ramping back up with China.
*   **“Big, beautiful bill”:** Senate Republicans will work this week on their version of the massive spending and tax cuts package advancing Trump’s domestic policy agenda. GOP leaders are trying to win over conservative critics concerned the bill will increase the federal deficit.
*   **Foreign policy frustrations:** Trump’s Middle East envoy slammed Hamas’ response to a US-backed Gaza ceasefire proposal Saturday, and skepticism surrounds the Russia-Ukraine peace talks planned in Istanbul on Monday. The president has faced diplomatic roadblocks as he tries to fulfill a campaign pledge to end the conflicts.
*   Trump pulled his NASA pick after top aide lobbied against the nominee, source says. Trump withdrew Isaacman’s nomination days after Musk, the SpaceX CEO who served as a senior adviser to the president, departed Washington with a plan to refocus on his companies. Trump selected Isaacman in December. Trump said on social media Saturday night that he pulled Isaacman’s nomination after a “thorough review of prior associations.” The White House said earlier Saturday that “It’s essential that the next leader of NASA is in complete alignment with President Trump’s America First agenda.” Records on OpenSecrets show Isaacman donated to Democrats as recently as the 2024 election cycle, though he donated to Republicans in prior years.
*   Rubio spoke with his Russian counterpart by phone today, State Department says. Secretary of State Marco Rubio spoke with Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov today, the US State Department said, ahead of a key meeting between Russian and Ukrainian delegations in Turkey. The call came “at Russia’s request.”
*   White House wasn't given a heads-up about major Ukrainian strikes on Russian bases, official says. The Trump administration was not briefed ahead of time about a significant and ambitious Ukrainian operation targeting Russian air bases this weekend, an administration official told CNN. Ukraine estimates that its operation against Russian air bases caused $7 billion in damages.
*   "Absolute disaster": Senate Democrats preview criticisms of Trump megabill. Senate Democrats previewed their arguments against the massive domestic policy bill that the upper chamber will now have to address. Sen. Chris Murphy of Connecticut called the bill an “absolute disaster” for middle class and poor Americans.
*   "We’ve got to keep the pressure on Hamas,". GOP senator says after return from Israel. The US needs to “keep the pressure on Hamas” to get remaining hostages out of Gaza, Republican Sen. Dave McCormick said today after returning from his trip to Israel, where he met with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. McCormick criticized Hamas for not agreeing to a US-backed ceasefire proposal. Hamas released a statement today saying it is ready to “immediately” begin indirect negotiations on resolving the remaining “points of contention” with the US-backed proposal. Cindy McCain, the executive director of the United Nations World Food Programme, warned today there will be a “humanitarian catastrophe” in Gaza “like none other” without an immediate ceasefire between Israel and Hamas.
*   Tariffs "are not going away," Trump's commerce secretary says. Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick emphasized today that President Donald Trump’s 90-day pause for tariff negotiations is a hard deadline — and vowed that despite a federal court ruling earlier this week, tariffs “are not going away.” The secretary predicted a “lot of deals” will be done ahead of the July deadline. Lutnick also weighed in on last week’s court ruling blocking tariffs that Trump imposed using emergency powers. The administration appealed the decision, and an appeals court ruled that the tariffs can remain in effect while the case is being heard. Trump claimed on Truth Social today that a ruling against him would mean “Economic ruination” for the country and allow other nations to take advantage of the US.
*   Musk defends DOGE as he distances himself from Trump’s agenda. Tech billionaire Elon Musk defended the Department of Government Efficiency in an interview aired today on CBS, arguing that his initiative became a scapegoat. Though he remained cordial and supportive during his farewell Oval Office appearance with President Donald Trump on Friday, Musk has more recently sharpened his criticism of the president.
*   Vought downplays role of Project 2025 in Trump policy agenda. Office of Management and Budget Director Russ Vought distanced himself from suggestions that he is implementing elements of Project 2025, a sweeping conservative policy blueprint he helped craft, into the Trump administration’s agenda.
*   GOP backers are pushing back on critics saying Trump’s bill will add to the deficit. Speaker Mike Johnson repeatedly denied today that the “big, beautiful bill” passed by the House last month will increase the national debt. The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office has predicted the bill could add around $3.8 trillion to the deficit over eight years. The Joint Committee on Taxation has since increased that estimate to $3.94 trillion.
*   Trump’s 50% tariffs on steel are a national security measure, top economic adviser says. White House National Economic Council Director Kevin Hassett defended President Donald Trump’s recent doubling of steel tariffs to 50%, framing the measure as a critical step to ensuring the United States is prepared in the event of war. Trump announced at a Pennsylvania steel plant Friday that he would set tariffs on steel imported into the US at 50% starting June 4.
*   House minority leader accuses Trump administration of trying to intimidate Democrats. House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries accused the Trump administration of trying to intimidate Democrats as confrontations with federal officials have escalated in recent weeks.
*   Bessent says Trump and Xi will speak "very soon" as trade tensions escalate. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping plan to speak “very soon,” but declined to set a date for the long-awaited, high-stakes conversation between the leaders as Trump and other top US officials appear to escalate tensions with Beijing.
*   OMB director pushes back on Musk's concern that Trump policy bill will increase deficit. Russ Vought, the director of the Office of Management and Budget, directly challenged criticism from Elon Musk and several Republican senators that President Donald Trump’s “big, beautiful” bill increases the federal deficit.
*   Trump calls on the Senate to pass his domestic policy bill and clarifies a key promise. President Donald Trump is urging the Senate to retain provisions from conservative hardliners in his expansive domestic policy bill. Trump returned to social media to spotlight a key tax cut promise from his campaign that was left out of the sweeping policy bill: no taxes on Social Security.
*   Trump ramped up his trade war again last week. President Donald Trump made the latest move in his ever-evolving trade war Friday, announcing at a Pennsylvania steel plant that he plans to double tariffs on the alloy. Trump told a crowd at the US Steel facility outside Pittsburgh that he plans to jack up tariffs on the material to 50%. Trump on March 12 imposed sweeping 25

title: A Québécois Socialist Response to Canada’s Federal Election
content: These elections took place in a climate of heightened Canadian nationalism. In Quebec, the Bloc adopted a nationalism compatible with federalism. Both forms of nationalism assume that national ...
resumen: In the recent federal election, despite predictions of a Conservative Party victory, the Liberal Party of Canada secured a fourth consecutive mandate. The campaign was dominated by concerns over the trade war and Donald Trump's threats, influencing voting intentions. The new government, led by Prime Minister Mark Carney, aims to defend the Canadian economy, reaffirm national sovereignty, and protect territorial unity. The Canadian bourgeoisie and its governments face pressure from a US administration. The election resulted in a minority government, highlighting a polarization around the two major neoliberal parties and marginalizing third parties. The Conservative Party championed an ultraliberal agenda, combining it with populist demagogy. The Liberal Party, under Carney, shifted right, adopting elements of the Conservative platform, while also promoting Canadian nationalism. The Bloc Québécois lost ground, and the independence movement faced an impasse. The left has been weakened by the NDP's actions, trade-union apathy, and the fragmentation of social movements. The Canadian and Quebec left can rebuild by breaking with nationalisms and uniting working classes, Indigenous peoples, and subaltern groups in a plurinational liberation project. This project must be feminist, anti-racist, socialist, and decolonial. It must link its action to an ecosocialist project. The results of the last elections show that everything must be rebuilt from a veritable field of ruins. André Frappier and Bernard Rioux are the authors of the article.

title: How a man described as ‘dumber than a sack of bricks’ came to dominate global trade policy
content: The decline has been unprecedented by US standards and has created, or at least compounded, what’s often referred to as a Rust Belt from the Midwest to the Great Lakes, an area that spans from western ...
resumen: Peter Navarro, described as "dumber than a sack of bricks" by Elon Musk, is a key adviser to Donald Trump on trade policy. Navarro, 75, is the intellectual driving force behind global tariffs and Trump's attempt to rewire the global trading system. He gained influence with his 2011 book "Death by China," which portrays China as a major issue in world trade, arguing that Beijing engages in unfair practices. Navarro played a role in the first Trump administration, but his push for a more aggressive stance on China was initially limited. He participated in the Rudy Giuliani-led campaign to overturn the 2020 US election result and spent four months in prison for refusing to cooperate with the congressional inquiry into the January 6th attack on the US Capitol. He was appointed Trump’s senior counsellor for trade and manufacturing. Navarro was the brains behind Trump’s reciprocal tariff formula, which had no precedent in economic theory. The formula generated weird outcomes, such as a 47 per cent tariff on Madagascar's exports. Navarro is spearheading this protectionist drive. His academic standing was affected when it emerged he fabricated a person frequently quoted in his books. Navarro used to write get-rich-quick investment books. The US has lost close to 5 million manufacturing jobs since 2001, the year China joined the World Trade Organisation (WTO). Navarro penned a chapter in Project 2025 called “the case for fair trade” in which he makes the argument for action against China’s “institutionalised aggression”. He states that the US’s big trade deficits have been so damaging.

title: Fed’s Waller Hints at Potential Rate Cuts Despite Tariff-Driven Inflation Risks
content: Federal Reserve Governor Christopher Waller said interest rate cuts remain on the table for 2025, even as President Donald Trumps new tariffs are expected to temporarily lift inflation. Speaking in ...
resumen: Federal Reserve Governor Christopher Waller said interest rate cuts remain on the table for 2025, even as President Donald Trump’s new tariffs are expected to temporarily lift inflation. Speaking in Seoul, Waller emphasized that he would “look through” the near-term inflationary impact of tariffs when setting monetary policy. If inflation keeps trending toward the Fed’s 2% target and the job market remains strong, Waller supports what he called “good news” rate cuts later this year. He noted that April’s inflation data and a resilient labor market provide space to monitor how the economy evolves amid trade uncertainty. Waller’s comments diverge from more cautious Fed voices, as he acknowledged short-term risks from higher import duties. He sees potential inflation spikes in the second half of 2025 but characterized them as likely one-time effects. He added that if tariffs stay around 10%, the full price impact may not be passed on to consumers. The Fed official highlighted that current inflation expectations from markets and professional forecasters remain stable. Waller also addressed rising bond yields, attributing them partly to growing concerns about U.S. debt and foreign investor sentiment amid protectionist trade policies. He warned that a "risk-off" mood among foreign buyers of U.S. assets could be emerging due to anti-investment signals from Washington. Overall, Waller’s remarks suggest that the Fed is prepared to adjust rates if economic conditions allow, despite political and inflationary headwinds tied to Trump’s evolving trade agenda.

title: 'This is a roller coaster ride': How Trump's tariffs turned the 'TACO' trade into Wall Street's biggest debate
content: Ongoing US-China trade tensions and volatile policy shifts have left investors caught between betting on tariff deescalations and bracing for increased uncertainty.
resumen:
The "TACO" trade, an acronym for "Trump Always Chickens Out," captures a growing belief among investors that the president talks tough on tariffs but rarely follows through. This has fueled a market tailwind in recent months.

This week, Trump lashed out at China, accusing the country of having "violated" its trade deal with the US. Bloomberg reported that the Trump administration plans to expand tech restrictions on China.

Stocks have not only erased their "Liberation Day" losses, but the S&P 500 (^GSPC) secured its best May since 1990 and had the best month since Nov. 2023.

Julie Beale, chief market strategist at Kayne Anderson Rudnick, referenced a reporter's question to Trump earlier in the week about the trade. In response, Trump slammed the term. Beale worries that this may cause Trump to be more resilient on tariffs.

Rapid policy shifts mean that the downside risk could become significantly more pronounced if Trump decides to hold firm on tariffs.

S&P Global chief economist Paul Gruenwald said, "This is a roller coaster ride. Not good for long-term planning and not good for corporate investment."

A Manhattan-based trade court struck down a wide swath of Trump's tariffs, citing legal issues. A federal appeals court paused that decision on Thursday.

Callie Cox, chief market strategist at Ritholtz Wealth Management, urged investors to look beyond the tariff drama and focus on economic data, especially the jobs report coming up next week, and what the Fed is doing in response to all of this data. Cox noted the Federal Reserve has limited ability to intervene if the economy weakens.

title: MICHAEL LUCCI: US Multinationals Must Exit China
content: President Trump first called upon American businesses to find an alternative to China in August 2019. Few executives listened. Since ...
resumen: President Trump first called upon American businesses to find an alternative to China in August 2019. China’s global behavior has ranged from thuggish to explicitly war-like, including covid duplicity, underwriting Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, fueling America’s fentanyl crisis, and preparing to invade Taiwan. Trump’s 2019 call has been completely validated. Investors should be asking U.S. multinational companies why they are still dependent upon China. American industry must execute its own Operation Warp Speed to rapidly extricate all sensitive supply chains from China. China is not a reliable jurisdiction for multinational companies. China began shattering global norms from the moment they entered the World Trade Organization in 2001, quickly dismissing intellectual property (IP) laws, ignoring trade rules, and leveraging state control to thwart competition and subsidize economic attacks upon America. China’s cheating accelerated while reciprocity was always delayed, allowing China to accumulate massive trade surpluses. The prospect of Chinese market access has been repeatedly dangled to keep U.S. businesses submissive. China signed a trade deal with President Trump on January 15th, 2020, then immediately reneged, falling well short of the new purchases they promised. The CCP continued to pillage $225 billion to $600 billion of U.S. intellectual property per year. China’s IP theft and industrial subsidies are part of a “deliberate and strategic” attempt by Beijing to skip research costs, deindustrialize global competitors, and ultimately undermine the manufacturing capacity (and thus defense production) of rivals. The CCP’s global malfeasance took center-stage during the covid pandemic. China lied about a lab leak that caused the catastrophic outbreak, then took extraordinary lengths to cover up its malfeasance. In violation of international law, China – with full knowledge of its lethality – delayed notifying the World Health Organization of the Wuhan contagion, all while travelers departed Wuhan for global destinations. The CCP directed its companies operating overseas to exfiltrate to China as much medical and personal protective equipment as they could obtain. It also nationalized its local production – sweeping up American companies operating in China, including General Motors and 3M – to produce medical supplies while denying export licenses to send medical products to America. In early 2022, China blessed Russia’s invasion of Ukraine and has since funded and supplied Russia’s war machine. Kaja Kallas, the E.U.’s top diplomat, describes China as the “main sponsor” or Russia’s war, and recently noted that 80% of dual-use (civilian and military) goods enter Russia from China. The CCP has also dialed-up shipments of nitrocellulose, a key component in munitions, and Iskander missiles that have targeted Ukrainian cities. China is also sowing chaos across the Middle East, implicitly backing the murderous Hamas terrorists. Social media platforms under Beijing’s sway have directed a disinformation campaign against the Jewish state in hopes of weakening the West’s support for Israel and thus undermining American interests. China’s leaders have liaised with Hamas’ leaders about the conflict. Large quantities of Chinese-made assault rifles, grenade launchers, sophisticated explosives and high-tech military equipment have reportedly been captured in Hamas warehouses. Chinese companies stand accused by the United States of providing Iranian-backed Houthis with satellite imagery and dual-use components to help them target American ships in the Red Sea. The Houthis have spared China-flagged ships in exchange for this assistance. Since Russia’s 2022 invasion of Ukraine, Chinese Communist Party leader Xi Jinping has been openly preparing to blockade and invade Taiwan. The PLA is hurtling toward conflict, from nearly constant invasion drills, to combat readiness measures, to crafting legal frameworks designed to justify an invasion. INDOPACOM Commander Samuel Paparo describes China’s drills as rehearsals for forced annexation. Two consecutive State Departments have found China to be engaged in genocide against minority groups, and the House Select Committee on the Chinese Communist Party found China’s government to be the “prime mover” in America’s fentanyl crisis. President Trump’s tariff reprieve is unearned grace for most companies still dependent upon China. U.S. multinationals must finally see the writing on the wall and accelerate their departure from China. Michael Lucci is the Founder and CEO of State Armor, a 501(c)(3) non-profit advocating for state solutions to the global threats posed by the CCP.

title: US Stock Market Live: China vows response to US accusation on trade deal violation
content: Futures on Wall Street have begun trading on Sunday evening US time on a negative note amidst rising uncertainties on trade and geopolitical tensions. Both US and China traded barbs over the weekend ...
resumen:
US Stock Market Live: Dow futures are down up to 150 points, while the S&P 500 and nasdaq futures are down 20 and 90 points respectively.

US and China traded barbs over the weekend for violating a trade agreement that was reached in Geneva last month.

US has accused China of curbing the exports of rare earth magnets and other key minerals, while China has called out the US for their curbs on semiconductor exports.

US President Donald Trump also announced that he will be doubling the tariffs on steel and aluminium to 50% from 25%.

Rising tensions between Russia and Ukraine have also sent oil prices higher.

Wall Street had their best month since November 2023 after benchmark indices gained up to 6% in May.

The US Dollar index is back at 99.

Chinese shares traded in Hong Kong fell on Monday.

The Hang Seng China Enterprises Index dropped as much as 2.9%.

The MSCI Asia Pacific Index down 0.8%.

The dollar will tumble to levels last seen during the Covid-19 pandemic by the middle of next year, according to predictions by Morgan Stanley.

The US Dollar Index will fall about 9% to hit 91 by around this time next year.

Manufacturing activity across several Asian nations weakened in May as US tariffs and trade uncertainty eroded demand.

In Vietnam, new export orders contracted for a 7th straight month.

In Taiwan, output and new export sales all fell for a second month.

Indonesia saw the steepest drop in new orders since August 2021.

South Korean manufacturers recorded the deepest decline in output in nearly three years.

Vietnam, Indonesia, Taiwan, Japan and South Korea all recorded a contraction in overall activity, with the Purchasing Managers Index remaining below the 50-no change mark.

Gold rose — after falling by 2% last week.

Bullion climbed as much as 0.8% in Asia.

Brent crude for August rose as much as 2.1% to $64.09 a barrel, after losing 2.2% last week, while West Texas Intermediate was around $62.

Ukraine struck air bases deep in Russia.

President Donald Trump said he would be increasing tariffs on steel and aluminum.

The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and its allies agreed on Saturday to add 411,000 barrels a day of supply in July.

Ukraine staged a dramatic series of strikes across Russia.

More than 40 Russian aircraft, including the Tu-95 and Tu-22 M3 long-range bombers capable of deploying conventional and nuclear weapons as well as the A-50, are reported to have been damaged in the operation on Sunday, an official in Ukraine’s Security Service said.

China Hits Back At US– US actions against China are discriminatory. – Repeatedly raised concerns regarding US abuse of export control measures in semiconductors. – Urge the US to correct its erroneous actions and uphold the consensus reached in Geneva.

US President Donald Trump told reporters: – China violated a big part of the agreement we made. – I’ll speak to President Xi and I’m sure we’ll work that out. However,. – China has not acknowledged Trump’s call demand with Xi yet. – Last instance of Trump-Xi talking was before Trump’s inauguration in January.

The Dow futures are down over 100 points, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq futures are down 20 points and 90 points respectively.

title: Chinese shares fall in Hong Kong on new trade frictions with US
content: Chinese shares traded in Hong Kong fell on Monday, as heightened US-China trade tensions jolted market sentiment. The Hang Seng China Enterprises Index dropped as much as 2.9%, the most in more than ...
resumen: Chinese shares traded in Hong Kong fell on Monday, as heightened US-China trade tensions jolted market sentiment. The Hang Seng China Enterprises Index dropped as much as 2.9%, the most in more than six weeks, led by losses in technology and electric vehicle companies. The index underperformed all of its Asian peers, with the MSCI Asia Pacific Index down 0.8%. The onshore market is closed for a holiday on Monday. Negotiations between the world’s two largest economies have deteriorated as they accused each other of walking away from the terms of their trade truce last month. President Donald Trump told reporters Friday that China “violated a big part of the agreement” the countries made in Geneva, while expressing confidence that a talk with Chinese President Xi Jinping could ease tensions. The Trump administration’s plans to broaden restrictions on China’s tech sector, with new regulations to capture subsidiaries of companies under US curbs, and place limits on Chinese students’ visas — also weighed on investor concerns. The Chinese government called on the US to immediately correct “discriminatory” measures and uphold the consensus reached at their Geneva talks, it said in a statement Monday. Chinese stocks’ weakness reflects “growing pressure and concern, such as renewed chip curbs,” said Billy Leung, investment strategist at Global X ETFs in Sydney. “In the near term, trade uncertainty, property weakness, and June liquidity stress could keep foreign flow light.” China’s residential property sales continued to fall in May, signalling the real estate slump is still weighing on an economy that’s under pressure from deflation and trade tensions. Despite a recent selloff, the offshore Chinese stocks gauge is still among the world’s top gainers so far this year, fueled by hopes for further domestic stimulus and artificial intelligence-driven optimism from local startup DeepSeek’s breakthrough. The HSCEI and the Hang Seng Index are both up over 12% year-to-date, beating a 6.7% gain in the MSCI Asia Pacific Index. A wave of listings by Chinese companies in Hong Kong is also stirring anticipation that a robust pipeline of debuts will drive the broader stock market higher.

title: President Trump Can’t Quiet Reality, Neither Can The Federal Reserve
content: U.S. President Donald Trump (R) shakes hands with his nominee for the ... More chairman of the Federal Reserve Jerome Powell during a press event in the Rose Garden at the White House, November 2, ...
resumen:
President Trump warned Walmart to not raise prices in response to his imposition of tariffs. Economists and pundits reacted to Trump’s warning with a mix of horror and haughty disdain.

The foolishness of tariff imposition is magnified when the individual behind the implementation demands that prices not reflect the initial error.

The Federal Reserve is being treated as the adult in the room relative to Trump’s much-ridiculed child. In pretending that the central bank has a role in mitigating Trump’s errors, the central bank comes off as Trump’s equal in the foolish department.

The Fed thinks it can do to soften the higher price implications of tariffs.

If the Fed’s answer is that economic growth causes prices to rise (the Fed sees higher prices as “inflation”), and that slower growth born of a higher Fed funds rate will weigh on prices, then economists should be reacting in horror and haughty disdain toward the Fed too.

Fed officials near monolithically embrace the discredited Phillips Curve, which says growth causes prices to rise.

Economic growth is an effect of investment, and it reveals itself in enhanced production techniques that increase production of market goods at ever lower prices.

The biggest informer of consumer prices is the number of tessellated hands and machines around the world at work in the production of market goods.

When global cooperation is compromised due to taxes like tariffs, or perhaps lockdowns, prices of market goods rise. Conversely, when meddling politicians leave production and people alone, cooperation soars in concert with falling prices.

The Fed is trying to arrogate to itself a role in tamping down the higher prices that it not unreasonably says will be an effect of his tariffs.

The Fed thinks it has a role here as it endlessly leaks to a compliant and rather worshipful media its fears about the price implications of the Trump tariffs.

The popular belief inside the Fed is that economic slowdowns push down prices.

Trump rates our scorn for wanting prices to not reflect his mindless imposition of tariffs, so does the Fed rate equal amounts of scorn for thinking its own market interventions can blunt those of the President.

title: Market Implications Of Tariff Litigation And AI Spending
content: Regardless of the outcome of the tariff litigation, tariffs are likely to continue in some form. Falling recession odds and AI spending continue to send stocks higher.
resumen: The Court of International Trade (CIT) struck down the majority of the tariffs implemented by the Trump administration. The sectoral tariffs, for example, those on autos and steel, were not impacted by this ruling. The tariffs removed include the 10% universal tariff, the reciprocal tariffs, and the specific tariffs targeting China, Canada, and Mexico. According to Strategas, this would remove about $220 billion in tariffs, leaving just $40 billion of those implemented since the start of the year. Within less than 24 hours after the ruling, the US Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit granted a stay. Therefore, the tariffs will remain in place, and the US will not yet need to refund the tariff revenue collected to date. This litigation could be a lengthy process, but even if the tariffs are struck down at the end of the litigation, President Trump has the legal authority to reimpose tariffs via alternative methods. According to Strategas, Sections 338 and 122 of the Tariff Act of 1930 can be utilized quickly to reinstate many of the tariffs that are currently at risk. Section 338 allows for tariffs of up to 50% that take effect 30 days after announcement, with no time limit on their duration. Section 122 gives the president the authority to impose tariffs of up to 15% with immediate effect, but these tariffs can only remain in place for 150 days without congressional approval. Furthermore, Section 301 of the Trade Act of 1974 permits the imposition of tariffs following an investigation by the United States Trade Representative (USTR). It is doubtful that tariffs will go away unless President Trump decides that they are. On the margin, the possibility that the courts could remove the tariffs leaves the Trump administration with less leverage to negotiate trade deals with other countries. The tax bill passed by the US House of Representatives was debt-neutral if the revenue from the tariffs was included in the scoring. The economic calendar has the critical monthly jobs report on Friday. Expectations are for nonfarm payroll job growth to slow to 125,000 from 177,000 in April. The unemployment rate is expected to remain steady at 4.2%. President Trump imposed a 50% steel tariff late last Friday.

title: The U.S. Right Loathes the E.U. How Are They Going to Negotiate Trade?
content: The Trump administration and the European Union are fast-tracking discussions toward a trade deal, but America’s right sometimes treats the bloc as more foe than friend.
resumen:
The United States’ populist right dislikes the European Union. This skepticism could have real consequences as Mr. Trump wages a trade war on the bloc.

President Trump has said that the European Union was formed to take advantage of America. Vice President JD Vance warned that Europe was retreating from its “fundamental values” during a speech in Munich this year. Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth called America’s continental allies “pathetic” in a leaked Signal chat. Laura Ingraham, the conservative TV host, said this year that Europeans do not share American values, citing European climate policies, differences in views of free speech, and the right to bear arms.

A recent Fox News opinion article about trade negotiations quipped that European negotiators “move slower than a French escargot.” David Sacks, now Mr. Trump’s cryptocurrency and A.I. czar, co-hosted the “All-In” podcast, where Europe has been described as “dysfunctional.”

A slice of Republicans have long been skeptical of the European Union, blasting it for being bureaucratic, for its embrace of regulation, and for its comparatively liberal stances on issues like climate change. About 18 percent rated the it very poorly last year, up from 14 percent in 2020, a Pew Research survey showed.

The United States is treating Europe more as a geopolitical rival. Jacob Funk Kirkegaard, a senior fellow with the Peterson Institute for International Economics, said that the E.U. should expect the worst in the ongoing trade negotiations.

The United States has agreed to the blueprint for a trade deal with Britain, but the 27-nation European Union has made less progress toward an agreement. Mr. Trump’s 50 percent tariff on European imports has been delayed until July 9 and is subject to a legal challenge.

Both the Treasury secretary and the commerce secretary have recently suggested that the E.U. bureaucracy was getting in the way of a deal. Mr. Trump has met regularly with European national leaders but until recently had not chosen to meet, or even talk, with Ursula von der Leyen, the president of the European Commission. Mr. Trump said during a cabinet meeting this year, “the European Union’s been — it was formed in order to screw the United States.”

Brando Benifei, the chair of the delegation for relations with the United States at the European Parliament, said that the attitude toward Europe appears very hostile.

Ms. von der Leyen warned on Thursday that Europe must think about how to fend for itself in a new and more antagonistic era.

Ignacio García Bercero, a nonresident fellow at the think tank Bruegel, said that to understand the new aggressiveness, you need to go outside of the world of trade.

Republicans often complain about bureaucracy and regulation when it comes to the European Union. The bloc more aggressively insists that social media sites police content on their websites. It also more intensely regulates large technology firms in general, and it has embraced green energy and attention to climate change in a way that the United States has not.

The European Union is 27 diverse nations.

Republicans and even some Democrats have taken issue with what they see as insufficient spending on defense among many European nations.

Mr. Trump recently wrote on Truth Social, “The European Union, which was formed for the primary purpose of taking advantage of the United States on TRADE, has been very difficult to deal with.”

Roughly half of Europeans consider Mr. Trump an “enemy of Europe,” said one survey commissioned by Le Grand Continent and Cluster 17 and conducted in the bloc’s eight largest countries earlier this year.

A rising group of populist leaders across the bloc and continent seem to be taking their cues from Mr. Trump.

Prime Minister Viktor Orban spoke at a gathering of right-wing politicians and said, “Brussels has stolen the European dream. Let’s make Europe great again!”

title: Ways Companies Can Navigate Trump’s Constantly Changing Tariff Policies
content: President Donald Trump’s on-again/off-again tariff policies have created a continuing crisis for many companies.
resumen:
President Donald Trump's on-again/off-again tariff policies have created an economic roller coaster for business executives.

A federal international trade court ruled Thursday that most of the tariffs were illegal, but another court reinstated the tariffs the next day, pending an appeal of the trade court’s decision by the Trump administration.

On April 2, Trump announced sweeping new tariffs targeting goods imported to the U.S. on countries including China, Japan and India.

David Warwick, a supply chain expert and an executive vice president at OverHaul, noted that companies are stuck in no man’s land, unsure whether to pass costs on to consumers, hold inventory, renegotiate contracts, or pivot to alternative suppliers.

Fabian Rivas, CEO of Enliven Interiors, observed that flexibility is key, along with diverse vendor relationships, proactive planning, and clear communication.

Jeremy Solomons, CEO of UK-based Export Management Services, said that companies should look at spreading their risk by sourcing from a wider range of countries, holding extra stock where it makes sense, and having contracts in place that allow for quick changes when needed.

Moshe Cohen, a senior lecturer at Boston University’s Questrom School of Business, advised maintaining relationships with suppliers.

Corey Dong, CEO of Enru Logistics, advised preparing and updating worst-case or next-case scenarios in anticipation of a decision by the appeals court.

Judi Durand, a crisis communications specialist at Judi Durand Consulting, said that companies need to be constantly proactive and public about how they are absorbing the impacts of the tariff volatility.

Cohen at Boston University recommended remaining opportunistic and locking in buying opportunities as they arise.

title: Why Trump Is Mad at the ‘Sleazebag’ Leonard Leo
content: Trump declared himself “so disappointed” in the Federalist Society because of its “bad advice” on judicial nominations. But he reserved his real venom for Leo, calling him a “sleazebag” and a “bad ...
resumen: On Thursday night, President Trump turned on one of his most important allies. A day after a three-judge panel from the U.S. Court of International Trade, which included a judge he appointed in his first term, rejected his use of the International Emergency Economic Powers Act of 1977 to grant him expansive tariff authority, Trump posted a rambling screed on Truth Social condemning the judiciary. He posted his rant in spite of the fact that the court’s decision was almost immediately stayed by a court of appeals while it considers the administration’s arguments. This time, however, he went after Leonard Leo and the Federalist Society. Trump declared himself “so disappointed” in the Federalist Society because of its “bad advice” on judicial nominations. But he reserved his real venom for Leo, calling him a “sleazebag” and a “bad person who, in his own way, probably hates America.” Leo helped Trump choose conservative lawyers and judges for both the judiciary and his administration. Trump’s decision in his first run for president to publish a Supreme Court short list stocked with leading lights of the Federalist Society helped him win over skeptical conservatives in 2016. The Federalist Society never capitulated to Trump. For every John Eastman — a Federalist Society luminary who was prosecuted and suspended from practicing law in California after he helped Trump try to steal the 2020 election — there are multiple Federalist Society judges and lawyers who’ve ruled against him or resisted him in other ways. During his first term, Trump had a worse record at the Supreme Court — which had a Republican-nominated majority — than any previous modern president. When he challenged the outcome of the 2020 election, Federalist Society judges ruled against him time and again. During Joe Biden’s term, the Supreme Court rejected several MAGA legal arguments, and during his second term so far, Trump is faring very poorly in federal court. According to an analysis by a political scientist at Stanford, Adam Bonica, as of May, Republican-appointed district judges ruled against Trump 72 percent of the time. The Supreme Court seems no more hospitable to Trump in his second term. It’s already unanimously ruled that deportees under the Alien Enemies Act are entitled to due process before deportation, it’s upheld a district court order requiring the Trump administration to facilitate Kilmar Armando Abrego Garcia’s return, and recently it ruled 7 to 2 against the administration in still another Alien Enemies Act case, holding that the administration was still not providing sufficient due process to deportees. Trump won important rulings at the Supreme Court that expanded presidential immunity and kept him on the ballot in 2024. When there is a conflict between conservative legal principles and Trump’s demands, conservative judges almost always adhere to their principles. Trump is baffled. At the beginning of his Truth rant, he refers back to the Court of International Trade and asks: “Where do these initial three Judges come from? How is it possible for them to have potentially done such damage to the United States of America? Is it purely a hatred of ‘TRUMP?’ What other reason could it be?” The core motivations of federal judges are very different from the core motivations of members of Congress. If you ask judges or members of Congress why they do what they do, you’ll likely get similar answers: They feel called to public service. In a court system built on precedents, not elections, it’s your decisions that measure your worth. Roger B. Taney was chief justice of the United States for 28 years, but when we hear his name one decision springs to mind — Dred Scott. He wrote the decision that stripped citizenship from Black Americans, rightly tarnishing his reputation forever. Many parts of the Constitution are intentionally counter-majoritarian. They’re designed to protect both individual rights and our republican form of government from majoritarian mobs. Due process is rarely popular, for example. And popular speech doesn’t need legal protection. The decision to protect their right not to speak is one of the Supreme Court’s finest moments. At their worst, federal judges can be arrogant and imperious. Both professionalism and pride are working together to preserve our constitutional order. If you try to intimidate a judge, you’re often confirming to the judge the necessity of her or his ruling. The combination of dedication to the rule of law and a kind of “How dare you?” stubbornness in the face of intimidation is resulting in one of the rarest spectacles in this miserable modern political era — one branch of government actually doing its job.

title: How Trump’s trade war is already effecting California’s ports
content: Chinese goods account for 40% of the imports at the Port of Los Angeles, 63% at the Port of Long Beach and 45% at the Port of Oakland.
resumen: California’s port traffic is beginning to look worse now, under the effects of President Donald Trump’s tariff policy, than it did at the height of the COVID-19 pandemic. Mario Cordero, chief executive of the Port of Long Beach, said in an interview with CalMatters in early May, “The vessel calls, or cancellations, that we’re seeing today (are) starting to exceed the number that we saw in COVID-19.” At Port of Los Angeles, Executive Director Gene Seroka said during a media briefing last week that the port expected 80 ships to arrive in May, but 17 have been canceled. Last year through May there were a total of 12 cancellations. There are 10 cancellations for June already. The Port of Oakland saw a 15% month-over-month drop in container activity in April. Martha Miller, executive director of the California Association of Port Authorities, said at a business roundtable last week that the unpredictability of Trump’s edicts means there won’t be a surge of cargo; many businesses are waiting to act, including to order goods for import. Data for the state’s three biggest ports confirm that jobs are dwindling for longshore workers up and down the state. Gary Herrera is president of the International Longshore Workers Union Local 13, which represents port workers in both Long Beach and Los Angeles. Part-time workers are not getting any hours right now. Full-time workers may not be getting 40 hours a week, either. Herrera was also speaking on behalf of a couple of other locals; altogether they represent about 9,000 full-time and 6,000 part-time port workers. Luisa Gratz is the president of International Longshore Workers Union Local 26, which represents most of the security on the docks in Los Angeles and Long Beach. Eric Tate is secretary-treasurer of Teamsters Local 848, which represents about 8,000 truck drivers in Southern California. He said truckers, especially part-timers who aren’t guaranteed any hours, are seeing less work, though he did say truckers saw a bit of a pickup in work after Trump temporarily reduced tariffs on China. The Port of Oakland is seeing a possible pickup in activity in June — as of last week, the planned canceled ships for that month have been reduced from 12 to five. The Trump administration reached with China on May 12, which lowers the tax on imports from China from 145% to 30% for 90 days. Stephanie Magnien Rockwell, chief of staff at the Port of Los Angeles, said in mid-May that California farmers are taking a hit. Chinese goods account for 40% of the imports at the Port of Los Angeles, 63% at the Port of Long Beach and 45% at the Port of Oakland. Seroka said to CalMatters, “We can’t generalize here, because of those 125,000 importing companies (whose) goods come through the Port of Los Angeles, but safe to say, if there was a little bit of a shortage on stock, or if some felt that the 30% average tariff might go higher, sure, people jump back in.” On May 23, Trump complained about not being able to reach a deal with Europe on tariffs and threatened a 50% tariff on European goods — which he said over the weekend would be delayed to July 9. He also threatened a 25% tariff on iPhones unless Apple begins to make the devices in the United States. Port of Long Beach CEO Cordero said a 10% decline in cargo could mean a 10% decline in jobs. He told CalMatters, “If you use a round figure of a million jobs stemming from the port operations, that’s a 100,000 job reduction.” The port supports jobs worth tens of billions of dollars in income in the five surrounding counties. In 2023, port activity contributed $84.4 billion in local, state and federal taxes. Kimberly Ritter-Martinez, the port’s manager of economics and funding, said during the Long Beach media briefing.

title: U.S. Court of International Trade Strikes Down Trump Tariffs as Beyond Presidential Authority, Illinois Leads Legal Victory
content: The U.S. Court of International Trade ruled Trump's sweeping tariffs exceeded presidential powers, a stance backed by a coalition of attorneys general.
resumen: La Corte de Comercio Internacional de EE. UU. declaró que la imposición de aranceles generalizados excede los poderes presidenciales. El Fiscal General de Illinois, Kwame Raoul, lideró una coalición de 13 fiscales generales en un desafío legal contra los aranceles. La corte determinó que se trataba de una extensión excesiva de la autoridad presidencial en virtud de la Ley de Poderes Económicos de Emergencia Internacional (IEEPA). Raoul dijo: "Una vez más, un tribunal ha evaluado el intento de la administración Trump de gobernar por decreto. Y una vez más, un tribunal ha dictaminado que el presidente excedió su autoridad en virtud de la ley". La acción legal, presentada por fiscales generales de estados como Arizona, Colorado y Nueva York, argumentó que la imposición de impuestos y aranceles es una prerrogativa del Congreso, postura que el tribunal mantuvo. Según la IEEPA, la autoridad presidencial para imponer tales aranceles se limita a emergencias que presenten una "amenaza inusual y extraordinaria" del extranjero, criterio que el tribunal consideró no cumplido por las acciones de la administración Trump. Raoul reiteró su compromiso con la defensa del gobierno constitucional, afirmando: "No somos una nación gobernada por decreto real. El estado de derecho sí importa, y no dejaré de defenderlo".

title: China sets up sets up international mediation body in Hong Kong
content: The mediation body aims to cement Hong Kong's presence as a top centre to resolve disputes between countries. Read more at straitstimes.com. Read more at straitstimes.com.
resumen: China signed a convention setting up an international organisation for mediation in Hong Kong on May 30. Beijing hopes it will be on par with the International Court of Justice and bolster the financial hub's international credentials. The mediation body aims to cement Hong Kong's presence as a top centre to resolve disputes between countries. Its status would be on par with the International Court of Justice and the Permanent Court of Arbitration of the United Nations in The Hague. It would help bring “substantial” economic benefits and job opportunities and stimulate various sectors including hospitality and transport. Indonesia, Pakistan, Laos, Cambodia and Serbia are among the countries attending the ceremony. Representatives from 20 international bodies including the United Nations were also expected to join. The scope of cases that would be handled include disputes between countries, between a country and nationals of another country and between private international entities. The new body would help Hong Kong cope with challenges that arise when “hostile external forces are attempting to de-internationalise and de-functionalise” the city. The new organisation’s headquarters will be located at a former police station in the bustling Wan Chai district, and is due to open by the end of this year or early 2026.

title: China-CELAC summit invests in multilateralism amid global trade tensions
content: At the summit in Beijing, Latin American leaders called for closer ties with China and sought new investment and trade opportunities.
resumen:
The China-CELAC summit took place in Beijing, with Latin American leaders calling for closer ties with China and seeking new investment and trade opportunities. The summit occurred amid a cooling in the tariff war between the United States and China.

The fourth ministerial summit between the Community of Latin American and Caribbean States (CELAC) and China took place earlier this month. Chinese President Xi Jinping underlined the start of a new, more united chapter of this relationship. CELAC leaders emphasized the need for a more balanced, multipolar world, and framed the bloc’s partnership with China as a pathway to greater autonomy in global affairs.

CELAC is a regional intergovernmental organization founded in 2010, bringing together all the countries of Latin America and the Caribbean. The China-CELAC Forum was established in 2014 to promote partnerships between the regions. Each previous China-CELAC summit has produced joint cooperation action plans.

Several national leaders attended the summit, including Colombia’s Gustavo Petro, Gabriel Boric of Chile, and Brazil’s Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva.

President Xi announced a CNY 66 billion (US$9.15 billion) credit line to support development in CELAC countries. Xi said that China and Latin America should expand cooperation on clean energy, artificial intelligence and the digital economy. He added that China will increase imports of “quality products” from Latin America, and that Chinese companies will be encouraged to expand investment in the region.

Boric claimed this as the time “to take a qualitative leap forward in economic ties with China”. Petro proposed a fibre optic cable to connect Asia with Latin America. Lula advocated for strong trade with China and deeper cooperation on the energy transition.

The China-CELAC Forum underlined its commitment to multilateralism and international cooperation, and to “strengthening all pillars of the climate change mechanism” in a 28-point joint statement.

The US recently dropped its tariffs on Chinese imports from 145 per cent to 30 per cent, while China signed off on a reduction from 125 per cent to 10 per cent. This will be reviewed in 90 days.

Petro confirmed Colombia’s joining of China’s Belt and Road Initiative (BRI). The BRI has expanded in the region over the past decade, and Colombia will become the 23rd CELAC country to sign up.

The Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) is a global infrastructure development strategy designed to boost trade and economic growth.

Francisco Urdinez, who directs the Millennium Nucleus on the Impacts of China in Latin America, said the summit’s main goal was to “show the world that multilateralism still exists and that free trade is still possible”.

Rebecca Ray, senior academic researcher for the Boston University Global Development Policy Center, agrees: “With trade barriers all over the place, it’s an important moment to come together and reaffirm commitment to multilateralism. The region is committing to pragmatic, open, non-discriminatory relations with the world to achieve its goals.”

Companies from China, Brazil’s primary trading partner, expressed their intention to invest approximately US$4.5 billion in various sectors of the Brazilian economy. According to the Brazilian Trade and Investment Promotion Agency (ApexBrasil), that will include renewable energy, mining, automobiles, food, logistics and the health sector.

Brazil issued a joint statement with China on the margins of the summit, in which both countries agreed to cooperate on projects related to the environment, energy transition and science and technology, among other areas.

The Chile-China Business Forum also took place in Beijing earlier this month. Both countries indicated a willingness to collaborate on solutions to challenges facing the energy transition and the digital transformation.

Nicaragua signed four agreements with Chinese companies on the margins of the summit, including a deal with Yutong on electric vehicles. Hydroelectric and mining deals were also floated.

Margaret Myers, managing director of the Johns Hopkins University’s Institute for America, China and the Future of Global Affairs, notes China’s lower credit commitment compared to previous summits.

title: Nvidia's Skyrocketing Growth Amidst U.S.-China Trade Tensions
content: Nvidia reported impressive 69% sales growth despite trade tensions between the U.S. and China, which threaten its operations. Restrictions on AI models from China and export curbs have impacted sales; ...
resumen: Nvidia reported impressive 69% sales growth despite trade tensions between the U.S. and China. Restrictions on AI models from China and export curbs have impacted sales. Nvidia remains optimistic about future growth due to international deals and strategic collaborations. Nvidia, the AI chip giant, has announced a staggering 69% sales growth for the quarter, while also highlighting challenges due to U.S.-China trade tensions. New restrictions on Chinese AI models could impact its business, as well as export curbs affecting its H20 chip sales. Nvidia remains confident, with significant international deals in the pipeline. CEO Jensen Huang praised President Trump's decision to rescind an export rule, but expressed concern over the absence of a new directive, warning of potential restrictions. Nvidia forecasts substantial growth, with projected sales of $45 billion in the upcoming quarter, driven by deals in the Middle East and Asia. Amid security concerns raised by U.S. senators about a new R&D facility in Shanghai, Nvidia maintains that the expansion is simply to accommodate existing employees. Nvidia's stock surged 4% as investor sentiment was boosted by a trade court decision blocking most of Trump's proposed tariffs.

title: A wealthy businessman challenging Guyana's president in an upcoming election faces new allegations
content: A wealthy businessman in Guyana who was sanctioned last year by the U.S. and who plans to challenge the South American country’s president in upcoming elections is facing new accusations.

title: Trump’s tariffs to remain in effect after appeals court grants stay
content: A federal appeals court temporarily reinstated the most sweeping of President Donald Trump’s tariffs on Thursday, a day after a trade court had ruled ...
resumen: A federal appeals court temporarily reinstated President Donald Trump’s tariffs on Thursday. The United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit in Washington said it was pausing the lower court’s ruling to consider the government’s appeal, and ordered the plaintiffs in the cases to respond by June 5 and the administration by June 9. Wednesday’s surprise ruling by the U.S. Court of International Trade had threatened to kill or at least delay the imposition of Trump’s so-called Liberation Day tariffs on imports from most U.S. trading partners and additional tariffs on goods from Canada, Mexico and China. The trade court’s three-judge panel ruled that the Constitution gave Congress, not the president, the power to levy taxes and tariffs, and that the president had exceeded his authority by invoking the International Emergency Economic Powers Act. Senior Trump administration officials said they were undeterred by the trade court’s ruling. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said in a Fox News interview that U.S. trading partners “are coming to us in good faith and trying to complete the deals before the 90-day pause ends.” Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney welcomed the trade court’s finding, saying it was “consistent with Canada’s longstanding position” that Trump’s tariffs were unlawful. Financial markets had reacted with cautious optimism to the trade court ruling, though gains in stocks on Thursday were largely limited by expectations that the court’s ruling faced a potentially lengthy appeals process. Analysts said broad uncertainty remained regarding the future of Trump’s tariffs, which have cost companies more than $34 billion in lost sales and higher costs, according to a Reuters analysis. Jeffrey Schwab, senior counsel for the Liberty Justice Center, said the appeals court would ultimately agree with the small businesses that faced irreparable harm. A separate federal court earlier on Thursday had also found Trump overstepped his authority in using the International Emergency Economic Powers Act for what he called reciprocal tariffs of at least 10% on goods from most U.S. trading partners and for the separate 25% levies on goods from Canada, Mexico and China related to fentanyl. Following a market revolt after his major tariff announcement on April 2, Trump paused most import duties for 90 days. George Lagarias, chief economist at Forvis Mazars international advisers, said, “Assuming that an appeal does not succeed in the next few days, the main win is time to prepare, and also a cap on the breadth of tariffs - which can’t exceed 15% for the time being.” The trade court ruling would have lowered the overall effective U.S. tariff rate to about 6%, but the appellate court’s emergency stay means it will remain at about 15%, according to estimates from Oxford Research. The effective tariff rate had been between 2% and 3% before Trump returned to office in January. Drinks company Diageo and automakers General Motors and Ford are among those that have abandoned forecasts for the year ahead.

title: US trade court rules Trump’s sweeping global tariffs are unlawful
content: Panel of judges finds Trump overstepped authority by imposing across-the-board duties on imports from trade partners.
