title: Federal trade court blocks Trump's emergency tariffs, saying he overstepped authority
content: A federal trade court ruled Wednesday that many of the tariffs President Trump has imposed so far exceeded his power under the International Economic Emergency Powers Act.
resumen: Un tribunal federal anuló muchos de los aranceles que Trump impuso este mandato, incluidos los aranceles mundiales generalizados que inquietaron a los consumidores y provocaron la caída de los mercados de valores. El fallo del Tribunal de Comercio Internacional dictamina que los aranceles que Trump impuso el 2 de abril a la mayoría de los países son ilegales. Trump ya tomó medidas para reducir temporalmente esos aranceles al 10 por ciento. El fallo también anula los aranceles separados que Trump impuso a China, Canadá y México, que la administración justificó como una reacción al tráfico de fentanilo. El tribunal escribió que los aranceles mundiales de Trump habían excedido su poder bajo la Ley de Poderes Económicos de Emergencia Internacional, o IEEPA, que la administración Trump citó al imponer esos aranceles. El tribunal escribió: "Debido a la asignación expresa de la Constitución del poder arancelario al Congreso... no interpretamos que la IEEPA delegue una autoridad arancelaria ilimitada al Presidente". El portavoz de la Casa Blanca, Kush Desai, dijo en un comunicado: "No corresponde a jueces no electos decidir cómo abordar adecuadamente una emergencia nacional". IEEPA, la ley en el centro del caso, nunca se había utilizado para imponer aranceles hasta que el presidente Trump lo hizo. El fallo se produjo en un caso presentado contra la administración por 12 estados y cinco empresas. El tribunal descubrió que el argumento del presidente, que los aranceles crearán influencia para que otros países tomen medidas enérgicas contra el tráfico de drogas, invalida los aranceles. Los jueces escribieron que, bajo la IEEPA, un arancel debe "tratar directamente" la emergencia que un presidente cita al imponer el arancel. Los aranceles al fentanilo no abordan directamente el tráfico de drogas, escribieron los jueces, sino que simplemente intentan crear presión económica dentro de otros países. Los tres jueces fueron nombrados por tres presidentes diferentes: Barack Obama, Ronald Reagan y el propio Trump. El fiscal general de Oregón, Dan Rayfield, celebró el fallo.

title: Macy’s slashes 2025 profit outlook as tariffs and inflation bite
content: Department store chains have consistently lost market share, and competition will likely intensify this year with inflation expected to jump.
resumen:
Macy's cut its annual profit forecast on Wednesday as the top U.S. department store operator navigates tariff-induced uncertainty and signaled early discounts on its spring collection to better manage its stock.

The company expects 2025 adjusted profit per share to be between $1.60 and $2.00, compared with the between $2.05 and $2.25 forecast earlier.

Macy's beat first-quarter estimates and maintained its annual net sales forecast of $21 billion to $21.4 billion.

Macy's net sales were $4.6 billion for the three months ended May 3, topping expectations of $4.5 billion, while adjusted profit per share of 16 cents beat estimates by 2 cents.

The company flagged a 10 cents to 25 cents per share impact on annual earnings from tariffs, adding that about 20% of its private brand products were sourced from China.

title: Passport Global Inc. Becomes Permitted Licensed Customs Broker, Unlocking New Era of Import Compliance & Duty Recovery for Ecommerce Brands
content: Announcement follows Passport's patent-pending Seller of Record® achievement and continued leadership navigating tariffs and de minimis reform under Trump-era trade changes. PALO ALTO, ...
resumen: Passport Global, Inc. (Passport), a leading global ecommerce solutions provider, announced it has been officially granted a U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) Corporate Customs License and National Permit. This positions Passport among a select group of providers authorized to act as permitted licensed customs brokers across all U.S. ports of entry. Alex Yancher, Co-Founder and CEO of Passport, stated that becoming a licensed customs broker strengthens their ability to protect customers, manage risk, and ensure compliance. With this license, Passport can file customs entries, represent importers, facilitate duty drawback, and offer compliance advisory services. These services include: File formal and informal customs entries directly into ACE, Represent importers of record (IOR) and manage Post Summary Corrections, Submit duty drawback claims for goods exported in the same condition, and Facilitate bonded shipments to bypass U.S. duty for in-transit cargo. Passport's Global Trade team of Licensed Customs Brokers already offers solutions including: Product classification consulting under the Harmonized Tariff Schedule (HTSUS), Customs valuation strategies, Origin declaration guidance for USMCA and other trade preference programs, and Support for Partner Government Agency (PGA) requirements. Traci Fisher, LCB, CCS, and License & Permit Qualifier at Passport, stated that the license reinforces their commitment to delivering trusted, end-to-end customs solutions. Passport can now work directly with CBP to manage the end-to-end drawback process, including: Eligibility screening and drawback program setup, Application filing for drawback privileges, Data reconciliation and CBP-approved claim preparation, and Advisory support to optimize drawback strategies. Thomas Taggart, VP of Global Trade at Passport, stated that duty recovery is a competitive edge. Max Christman, Supply Chain & Operations Lead at OneSkin, stated that Passport has proven to be the most effective for getting their products to customers. Passport's license adds a new layer of control to its cross-border infrastructure. Passport was founded in 2017.

title: Why China stocks are back in favor for Wall Street
content: JPMorgan Chase & Co. equity derivatives strategists see the worst of trade uncertainty in the rear view mirror, while Goldman Sachs Group Inc. is expecting the yuan to strengthen versus the dollar, ...
resumen: Since slumping to a four-month low in April, Chinese equities have rallied nearly 25% as US-China trade tensions eased. According to 22V Research, that’s left the stocks vulnerable to yet another selloff in coming weeks and months. The end to a temporary trade truce in August, an upcoming meeting of China’s Politburo and the potential passage of the US president’s tax-and-spending package all risk reigniting turbulence in the market, 22V’s strategists say. That means now is an opportune time to buy protection against any declines in the form of three-month puts on a popular US-listed proxy for the Asian nation’s biggest publicly traded companies, the roughly $6 billion iShares China Large-Cap ETF (ticker: FXI). “The US-China outlook is now likely to be noisier and messier in coming months,” 22V’s strategists wrote in a note dated Friday. “If Congress passes the fiscal bill by its August recess, Trump will have less incentive to keep trade tensions in check.” In the past year alone, the FXI has weathered five swings of around 25% or more in either direction. On Tuesday, US-listed shares of PDD Holdings Inc., the owner of e-commerce website Temu, took a 14% plunge, driven by an earnings miss on slowing growth. US warnings on the use of Huawei Technologies Co. chips for artificial intelligence signal more tension could be on the way as the Trump administration looks to blunt Chinese tech advances. “When I look at the index and I see the realized volatility that you’ve had, you have potential events coming up and you have vol back at the lows, it just seemed to line up,” said Jeffrey Jacobson, 22V’s head of derivative strategy, in an interview Tuesday. Continued demand for bullish calls is in turn making puts relatively cheap, given the clear downside risks. Amy Wu Silverman at RBC Capital Markets said while both upside and downside options on FXI look “notably cheap,” investors are wary of hedging too far ahead into the future, given Trump’s habit of delaying tariff implementation. Investor sentiment appears evenly divided as skew, a common metric for measuring the cost of puts versus bullish calls, remains well balanced in global equity markets. FXI calls are in demand from investors who are the using bullish options to ensure they benefit from the upside if trade talks are successful, according to Wu Silverman. “If President Trump, at any given time, can add T+60 days, how can I think about the mechanism of hedging that?” she added. “That’s one reason you don’t see this massive pick up in skews.” “The risk I actually see is the idea of the pain trade being to the upside,” said Wu Silverman. JPMorgan Chase & Co. equity derivatives strategists see the worst of trade uncertainty in the rear view mirror, while Goldman Sachs Group Inc. is expecting the yuan to strengthen versus the dollar, boosting Chinese equities due to stronger earnings. To Chang Shu, chief Asia economist at Bloomberg Economics, the mood among Chinese corporates remains dour, as a final deal is unlikely to change the significant levies China now faces on exports to the US. Trump’s sheer unpredictability makes it hard to guarantee the long-term fate of any US trade detente with China, she said.

title: A big, beautiful EU trade deal with Trump? Dream on!
content: European politicians have no appetite to give the White House big concessions and revisit the inflammatory topics that dominated the TTIP talks a decade ago.
resumen: European politicians have no appetite to give the White House big concessions and revisit the inflammatory topics that dominated the TTIP talks a decade ago. Donald Trump is already celebrating that his tariff threat has forced the EU to stop "slow walking" and make a deal. Europe and the United States are not expected to strike a far-reaching trade deal because U.S. President Donald Trump is threatening to impose tariffs of as much as 50 percent on EU goods by July 9. Europe has no political appetite to revisit the nightmare of its last attempt to forge a sweeping EU-U.S. trade pact — the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership. A rushed deal to satisfy America's core trade interests nearly a decade later would prove equally traumatic and toxic. France and Germany know their electorates have not tempered their hostility to chemically rinsed chicken and still fear U.S. corporates would use international arbitration clauses to undermine EU health and environmental standards. At most, a cosmetic mini-truce could be in the offing to give Trump a symbolic political win. This mini deal may identify some low-hanging fruit, it is many miles from the vaulting ambition of TTIP, which envisioned regulatory alignment across the Atlantic. EU trade chief Maroš Šefčovič and U.S. Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick will seek to cool tensions over metals, cars, pharmaceuticals and other sectors targeted by Washington’s trade investigations. A separate, more technical track will negotiate the baseline tariff, which is currently at 10 percent although Trump is threatening to lift it to 50 percent. Brussels has already offered to drop its (relatively low) tariffs on industrial goods and to team up on tackling the glut in Chinese exports. Other potential tidbits include recognizing U.S. safety standards on cars and dropping duties on American ethanol. In 2025, Paris and Berlin are being very clear on the limits of what can be agreed. Germany’s new Chancellor Friedrich Merz has toned down his campaign claims that sealing a TTIP 2.0 “in the medium term” was a good idea. French Finance Minister Éric Lombard dared to revive the ghost of TTIP — only to be put back in his box a day later by the office of French President Emmanuel Macron. Jean-Luc Demarty, head of the European Commission’s trade department during the TTIP negotiations, also shivered at the idea of a return to that kind of wide-ranging diplomacy. An added disincentive to making concessions to Trump is that he has shown he will happily tear up any deal that he strikes. Josh Lipsky, senior director at the Washington-based Atlantic Council think tank, said that being part of a free-trade agreement is no guarantee that you will not be subject to these tariffs. Since taking office Jan. 20, Trump has antagonized the EU more than ever. Brussels has meanwhile been frustrated as its appeals for universal tariff disarmament have fallen on deaf ears. David Henig of the European Centre for International Political Economy said that the U.S. side today, “they don't know what they're looking for, but it doesn't seem like what they are looking for is likely to be any kind of an orthodox deal”. The EU is placing its bet on modest progress. Ignacio García Bercero, who was then the EU’s chief negotiator for the deal, said that it became very clear that it was going to become extremely hard to find a way to reach an agreement that the European Union would have been able to present as being balanced. TTIP initially seemed straightforward, such were the huge potential economic benefits for both sides. Then-trade commissioner Karel De Gucht said it would put up to an additional €545 in the pockets of European families every year. A political backlash over the secrecy of the talks as well as worries over environmental, health and labor standards eventually doomed the agreement. An obscure arbitration scheme, known as the investor-to-state dispute settlement mechanism, heightened tensions because it was seen as giving disproportionate power to multinationals in challenging European rules. Trump had originally set an impossible June 1 deadline to do a deal before 50 percent tariffs kicked in. After a “very nice call” with von der Leyen, however, the two sides pushed the deadline to July 9. An agreement recognizing U.S. standards on car safety could help bring more American cars to the EU. Brussels could also take a page from the U.K.’s agreement with Trump and allow U.S. ethanol into the EU duty-free. A spokesperson for ePURE, the European renewable ethanol association, said that a similar deal with the EU would mean the same threat for the industry in Europe, where farmers are subject to stricter regulations and without [genetically modified] crops. An EU diplomat said that the mood is one of pervasive fatalism that the U.S. will not prove an honest broker.

title: Carney invites Mexico’s President to G7 summit, raising hopes for sideline tariff talks with Trump
content: Prime Minister Mark Carney has invited Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum to attend the Group of Seven Leaders’ Summit in Kananaskis, Alta., next month, two sources familiar with the matter say.
resumen:
Prime Minister Mark Carney has invited Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum to attend the Group of Seven Leaders’ Summit in Kananaskis, Alta., next month, according to two sources.
Ms. Sheinbaum’s inclusion would provide an opportunity for talks with U.S. President Donald Trump on his protectionist tariffs and the future of North America’s trilateral trade agreement.
It would be the first three-way meeting between the leaders of Canada, Mexico and the United States since Mr. Trump took office.
The Globe and Mail is not naming the two sources because they are not authorized to discuss the matter publicly.
Mexico’s embassy in Canada declined to confirm the invitation or to offer comment.
Goldy Hyder, president of the Business Council of Canada, has been pushing the Carney government to invite Ms. Sheinbaum to Kananaskis.
Mr. Hyder said that Mr. Trump has fondness for Ms. Sheinbaum.
The U.S. President’s trade war on Canada and Mexico, which began in March, is discouraging capital investment in Canadian industry and has driven up costs for consumers and businesses.
The G7 summit is being held just outside Calgary.
On May 6, during a face-to-face visit in Washington with Mr. Carney, Mr. Trump told journalists he’s not sure the trilateral United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) is still relevant.
In an interview with CBC’s Power and Politics on Tuesday, Mr. Carney said there have been intensive discussions since then to work out a trilateral trade deal.
He indicated that a deal could be struck before September.
Flavio Volpe, president of the Auto Parts Manufacturers Association, said he thinks the fact that Mr. Carney has invited Ms. Sheinbaum to the G7 indicates that continuing trade talks between Canada and the United States are going well.
Fen Hampson, a professor of international affairs at Carleton University, said he thinks future trade talks with the U.S. might lead to a set of sectoral agreements – on autos, or steel – that could potentially even replace the USMCA.
Mr. Hyder said the Prime Minister’s invitation to his Mexican counterpart will help repair strained relations because of mismanagement by former prime minister Justin Trudeau and comments of Premier Doug Ford.
Mr. Hyder has meet Ms. Sheinbaum on two recent occasions.
Mr. Hyder expects Mr. Trump will push hard for a common position on how to deal with China and its unfair trade practices.
Canada and Mexico have each been holding bilateral talks in Washington with the Trump administration on defence and security matters as well as critical minerals.
Mr. Hyder said International Trade Minister Dominic LeBlanc was in Washington last week for talks on these issues with U.S. Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick.
Canada’s ambassador to Washington, Kirsten Hillman, said earlier this month she sees discussions on security – including the illegal distribution of fentanyl – and matters such as critical minerals taking place separately from the renegotiation of the USCMA, which is up for renewal in 2026.
The current U.S. levies on Canada that remain in effect include 25-per-cent tariffs on Canadian steel and aluminum, as well as a 25-per-cent tariff on Canadian-made vehicles, which applies only to the non-U.S. content in those cars and light trucks.
There is also a 25-per-cent tariff – which drops to 10 per cent on critical minerals, energy and potash – for goods that don’t comply with rules of origin in USMCA.
Canada responded with a series of countertariffs on tens of billions of dollars of U.S. imports.

title: Donald Trump steals Xi Jinping’s favourite foreign policy
content: In February Mr Trump halted graft investigations under the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, blaming the law for erecting “excessive barriers to American commerce”. Though Mr Trump loves economic ...
resumen: China, a major economic and military power, often adopts a cautious and transactional approach to foreign policy, particularly in regions like the Middle East. This approach, focused on business deals and self-interest, has persisted under Xi Jinping, who presents China as a peace-loving giant to the world while emphasizing its global pre-eminence at home. China promotes prosperity through trade, technology, and infrastructure as a solution to regional conflicts, as seen with the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI). China's foreign policy is often praised as "Chinese wisdom" by scholars. China has vetoed UN Security Council resolutions to impose sanctions on Syria. China's primary interest in Syria's civil war was the presence of Uyghur militants. China's response to problems is to call for mediation and suggest that Western intervention is the root cause. China favors opaque contracts and is a stingy aid donor. Donald Trump, the American president, shares a transactional approach to foreign policy, and is scornful of overseas aid. Trump praised Gulf Arab rulers for focusing on commerce rather than chaos. Trump halted graft investigations under the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act. China's economy is slowing, and BRI lending has peaked. China remains a major energy buyer and offers green technologies. Trump has given China cause to amp up the ideology, and push harder.

title: Tired of tariffs? 5 investments to step off the Trump tariff merry-go-round
content: Investors have seen a lot of volatility so far in 2025, as they try to grapple with the impact of new tariffs from the Trump administration on the economy. The S&P 500 rose to start the year, but fell ...
resumen:
In 2025, investors have seen volatility due to the impact of new tariffs from the Trump administration. The S&P 500 rose to start the year, but fell sharply, entering a bear market, following the announcement of the new tariffs on “Liberation Day.” The market has since recovered much of its losses.

Five tariff-resistant investments:

1.  **Gold:** Up more than 25 percent so far this year, and has risen about 6 percent since the tariffs were announced.
2.  **Real estate:** Real estate tends to be impacted more by local issues.
3.  **International stocks:** The Vanguard FTSE All-World ex-US ETF (VEU) is up about 14 percent this year as of mid-May, compared to a roughly 1 percent increase for the S&P 500.
4.  **Bonds:** Bonds may provide some protection during times of uncertainty.
5.  **Individual stocks or industries:** Tech companies such as Uber Technologies (UBER) and Netflix (NFLX) are up more than 45 and 30 percent, respectively, in 2025. Traditional defensive sectors such as consumer staples, health care and utilities may also be places to ride out the tariff storm.

title: iPhone exports from India to US surge 76% in April, but trade policies remain tricky
content: Omdia reports iPhone exports from India to the US rose 76% in April as Apple shifts assembly to India amid US-China trade tensions.
resumen:
iPhone exports from India to the US rose 76% in April.
Apple is shifting assembly from China to India amid trade tensions.
Apple plans to manufacture most US-sold iPhones in India.
Exports of iPhones from India to the United States rose by an estimated 76% year-on-year in April, according to data from Canalys, now part of Omdia.
Omdia estimates that 3 million iPhones shipped from India to the US in April, compared with 900,000 units from China—a 76% fall from the previous year.
The shift reflects Apple's long-term strategy to diversify production amid increasing tariffs.
Apple began strengthening its manufacturing presence in India during the Covid-19 pandemic.
India first overtook China in US-bound iPhone shipments in March.
Apple’s shipment volumes spiked ahead of the tariffs' introduction on April 2.
An exemption for iPhones and other consumer electronics was introduced on April 11.
Apple CEO Tim Cook confirmed in early May that most iPhones sold in the US will be manufactured in India going forward.
Tariffs on Chinese-made iPhones remain in effect, currently subject to an additional 30% duty, while imports from India face a 10% baseline rate.
Growth in iPhone exports from India is expected to slow in the coming months.
India’s manufacturing infrastructure is still developing and may not be able to meet full US demand before 2026.
Current quarterly demand for iPhones in the US stands at around 20 million units.
Most sub-assembly processes still take place in China.
Trump threatened to impose a 25% tariff on all iPhones sold in the US unless they are manufactured domestically.
China has also reportedly imposed restrictions on the transfer of machinery and skilled labour to India.

title: Trump shock: Here’s a 4-D formula for policymakers to track it
content: As uncertainty rules high for companies, investors and governments, how matters move in terms of diversification, defence, debt and the dollar could help us gauge the impact of the Trump shock on the ...
resumen:
The article discusses a 4-D formula for policymakers to track the impact of the "Trump shock" on the Indian economy over the medium term, focusing on diversification, defence, debt, and the dollar.

Diversification: Countries may diversify their economic structures amid geopolitical uncertainty through bolstering manufacturing, depending more on domestic demand, increasing domestic savings, and restricting trade within regional economic zones. A higher share of wages in national income may be needed to support local consumer spending.

Defence: Global military spending increased in real terms at the fastest rate since the end of the Cold War in 2024. India may need to increase its military budget, potentially doubling it to 4% of GDP.

Debt: Bond markets are threatening action against countries with high public debt. India's public debt-to-GDP ratio is projected to decrease marginally between 2024 and 2030, with most government debt held by domestic investors.

Dollar: The US dollar has been the pivot of the global financial system. Concerns about the sustainability of US public finances are important. If the US dollar is toppled from its perch as the global reserve currency, it will impact every open economy that uses the US dollar as its main currency for international trade, whose central bank holds its reserves primarily in US dollar assets and whose exchange rate is maintained in some fixed or crawling leg to the US currency. India is one of those countries.

The author is Niranjan Rajadhyaksha, executive director at Artha India Research Advisors.

title: Japan Will Spend $6.3 Billion to Shield Its Economy From Trump’s Tariffs
content: Lawmakers approved a plan to help companies and consumers as officials bargain in Washington for relief from debilitating auto levies.
resumen:
Japan aprobó un paquete de gastos de $6.3 mil millones para "apoyar plenamente" a las empresas y los hogares afectados negativamente por los aranceles, dijo el secretario del gabinete Yoshimasa Hayashi en una sesión informativa. Los fondos reforzarán las finanzas de las pequeñas y medianas empresas y subsidiarán los costos de energía de los hogares.

El sector automotriz del país, la columna vertebral de la economía, ya se está tambaleando por un arancel estadounidense del 25 por ciento sobre automóviles y autopartes terminados.

Toyota Motor, la empresa más grande de Japón, ha proyectado un impacto de $1.3 mil millones en sus ganancias solo para abril y mayo debido a los aranceles. Honda Motor y Nissan Motor han pronosticado de manera similar fuertes caídas en sus ganancias. Nissan está considerando cerrar dos plantas en Japón como parte de sus esfuerzos de reestructuración. El fabricante de automóviles también planea trasladar parte de la producción de Japón a Estados Unidos para evitar los aranceles.

Los economistas han estimado que los aranceles automotrices más altos por sí solos podrían reducir significativamente la economía de Japón este año. Teniendo en cuenta las interrupciones más amplias causadas por las tensiones comerciales mundiales, los funcionarios han advertido que el crecimiento general podría reducirse a más de la mitad.

Antes de Japón, varios países reunieron fondos para ayudar a sus economías a hacer frente a la escalada de los aranceles. España dio a conocer un paquete de ayuda arancelaria de $15 mil millones el mes pasado. Canadá también ha destinado miles de millones de dólares para ayudar a sus trabajadores y empresas a capear el comercio turbulento con Estados Unidos.

El principal negociador de aranceles de Japón, Ryosei Akazawa, se reunió la semana pasada en Washington con sus homólogos de la administración Trump. Las conversaciones se han movido lentamente, estancándose al menos en parte porque los funcionarios de Trump han señalado que la principal demanda de Japón, una exención de los aranceles automotrices, no está sujeta a negociación.

El artículo fue escrito por River Akira Davis y Hisako Ueno.

title: Republican senator admits Trump is Canada’s ‘adversary’ as DC delegation grovels in Ottawa
content: Months of provocative statements about the Great White North joining America as the 51st state in the Union, however, led the delegation’s lone Republican member to admit to reporters that the US ...
resumen:
Washington’s delegation to Canada seemed to have one message in mind: please keep taking us seriously.

The delegation was split between four Democrats and one lone Republican senator representing a border state — North Dakota. Other Republicans stayed home.

Kevin Cramer, the GOP “co-leader”, told reporters that Prime Minister Mark Carney centered him in his conversation with the group, given the senator’s relationship with the Republican US president.

He told reporters that he sought to encourage Canadian officials to reach a trade deal with the United States.

Cramer said after the meetings Friday, according to Punchbowl News: “I don’t want to get in Donald Trump’s way. There’s no [trade] deal that happens without his involvement. But at the same time [I want to] be an encourager to Canada and their officials and try to be a partner in some way.”

Cramer did not take a beating on Truth Social, even though he did lay the blame for the fraying of ties squarely on Trump’s shoulders.

“We have an obligation to stop the offenses,” the Republican senator told reporters, speaking of the United States.

“For the moment, the United States has become an adversary to the Canadian people because of the offense that so many have felt,” he continued. “What I would stress with the president would be, let’s keep our eye on the common adversary and how much stronger we can be.”

Cramer said: “I’m just here to say thank you, and then to encourage Canadians to take another look and give us another chance.”

Tim Kaine pitched Carney on his bill to block US sanctions on Canada.

Senator Jeanne Shaheen said that she hoped some of the “cracks” in the bonds between the US and Canada could be healed.

Carney, elected on a Liberal Party mandate to stand up to the US president, flew to Washington in early May after telling the BBC in an interview that Canada would negotiate with America “on our terms”.

The Canadian prime minister reportedly invited Claudia Sheinbaum to the upcoming G7 summit in Kananaskis next month.

Carney told Trump that Canada was “not for sale” during their meeting at the White House in early May.

The US president wrote on Truth Social that he presented Canada’s government with a $61bn price tag to be involved with the US’s proposed “Golden Dome” missile defene system, adding that it would be free if Canada relented and became a state.

“They are considering the offer!” Trump said.

In an address scripted by the Canadian government, Charles declared that Canada, under Carney’s government, would bond with “reliable trading partners and allies” — a clear warning shot for Washington.

He’d add that Canada’s government was determined to protect the right to “self-determination” for the country.

Charles said on Tuesday: “We must be clear-eyed: the world is a more dangerous and uncertain place than at any point since the Second World War. Canada is facing challenges that are unprecedented in our lifetimes.”

title: ASEAN leaders agree tariff deals with US should not harm fellow members
content: Southeast Asian leaders reached an understanding on Tuesday that any bilateral agreements they might strike with the United States on trade tariffs would not harm the economies of fellow members, ...
resumen:
Southeast Asian leaders reached an understanding on Tuesday that any bilateral agreements they might strike with the United States on trade tariffs would not harm the economies of fellow members, Malaysia’s premier Anwar Ibrahim said.

Anwar, the current chair of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, said there was consensus during an ASEAN summit in Kuala Lumpur that any deals negotiated with Washington would ensure the interests of the region as a whole were protected.

The ASEAN meeting came at a time of global market volatility and slowing economic growth, and amid uncertainty over a trade war that has ensued since U.S. President Donald Trump’s announcement of sweeping “Liberation Day” tariffs.

Southeast Asia is among the regions hardest hit by the tariffs, with six of its countries facing levies of between 32% and 49% in July if negotiations on reductions fail.

“While proceeding with bilateral negotiations …, the consensus rose to have some sort of understanding with ASEAN that decisions should not be at the expense of any other country,” said Anwar, who on Monday said he had written to Trump requesting an ASEAN-U.S. meeting on the tariffs.

“So we will have to protect the turf of 650 or 660 million people,” he said of ASEAN.

ASEAN, a region with combined gross domestic product of more than $3.8 trillion, is in a precarious position in relation to the United States, which is the biggest market for the region’s exports, key drivers of its growth.

The 10-member bloc on Tuesday released a five-year strategic plan to better integrate its economies, citing challenges that meant “carrying on business as usual will not suffice”.

Tuesday’s meetings also included an economic gathering of leaders of the ASEAN, Gulf countries and China, which was represented by Premier Li Qiang.

One absentee was Brunei’s 78-year-old ruler, Sultan Hassanal Bolkiah, who was admitted to a Kuala Lumpur hospital after feeling tired, but was in good health according to his office.

At a dinner event late on Tuesday, China’s Li urged Gulf and ASEAN countries to remove trade barriers and expand liberalization in the face of rising protectionism and unilateralism.

ASEAN leaders also called for a temporary ceasefire in army-ruled Myanmar to be expanded nationwide, to enable warring sides to build trust and work towards convening dialogue.

Myanmar has been in crisis since its military overthrew an elected civilian government in 2021, triggering pro-democracy protests that morphed into a widening rebellion, with more than 3.5 million people displaced.

A devastating earthquake in March that killed more than 3,800 people led to a series of temporary ceasefires in affected areas of Myanmar, but the military government has continued air strikes and artillery attacks.

“We further called for the sustained extension and nationwide expansion of the ceasefire in Myanmar, as an initial step towards the cessation of violence,” ASEAN leaders said in a statement.

“We encouraged all relevant stakeholders in Myanmar to build trust towards convening an inclusive national dialogue.”

Anwar hailed “significant” engagement steps on Myanmar on Monday after last month holding a closed-door meeting in Bangkok with junta chief Min Aung Hlaing and virtual talks with the rebel-aligned shadow National Unity Government.

On Tuesday, Anwar said ASEAN leaders had agreed that the path forward was to engage all sides in Myanmar.

title: European Midday Briefing: Stocks Edge Higher Amid Easing Trade Concerns
content: Consumer prices were 0.6% higher on year this month, down from 0.9% in April, according to EU-harmonized figures published Tuesday by France's statistics agency Insee. Economists had expected May's ...
resumen:
European stocks ticked higher Tuesday on easing trade tensions, with Germany's DAX hitting a record high. The European Union agreed yesterday to fast-track talks with the U.S., after President Trump on Sunday pushed back plans to impose a 50% tariff on the bloc.

Stock futures rose as markets returned following the Memorial Day holiday. All eyes will be on a consumer confidence survey for May. Another preliminary survey from University of Michigan released earlier pointed towards further weakening in consumer sentiment in early May.

The euro slipped against the dollar. The dollar fell as uncertainty over U.S. tariffs remains elevated. The DXY dollar index could fall to 98.000.

The 10-year Bund yield fell, and is expected to hover around 2.5% for now amid trade difficulties between the U.S. and Europe. A fall to 2.2% is possible "if there is lasting re-escalation". UniCredit expects eurozone government bond supply to decline in June but to remain above 100 billion euros. Eurozone sovereigns have issued 660 billion euros in government bonds year-to-date, equivalent to more than 50% of their total issuance objectives for the year. Yields on U.K. government bonds fell, tracking moves in eurozone bonds, as trade tensions ease. Long-end Treasury yields dropped as investors returned to the market with caution, awaiting May's consumer confidence survey.

Oil prices slipped with investors looking ahead to OPEC's meeting on Sunday to review its supply agreement. Lower prices in 2025 through 2026 could lead to an earlier and lower peak for U.S. shale production, Goldman Sachs said.

Gold futures slumped, extending losses seen on Monday. Signs that Trump is easing his stance on trade with the EU has dented safe-haven demand, ANZ said.

The U.S. Marines recently took position in a field on this sleepy Swedish island about 200 miles from the Russian city of Kaliningrad and fired their mobile rocket system.

Thyssenkrupp plans to make all of its divisions independent and open to outside investment, a major overhaul that aims to turn the German industrial group into a holding company after more than two centuries as a manufacturer. The company said Monday that it would start preparations to separate its materials-services and automotive-technology segments in the coming years and that its decarbonization-technologies unit would follow suit. It aims to retain a majority interest in its businesses in the medium term.

Consumer sentiment in Germany improved a little as wage expectations grew and views of the economic outlook calmed, despite the uncertainty provoked by President Trump's tariff policies, a monthly survey said Tuesday. The consumer-climate index published by research groups GfK and the Nuremberg Institute for Market Decisions ticked up for a third straight month to minus 19.9 in June's forecast, 0.9 points higher than in May. Economists polled by The Wall Street Journal expected the measure a little stronger, at minus 19.6.

French inflation cooled more than expected in May, likely clearing the way to an expected European Central Bank interest-rate cut next month. Consumer prices were 0.6% higher on year this month, down from 0.9% in April, according to EU-harmonized figures published Tuesday by France's statistics agency Insee. Economists had expected May's rate to stay at 0.9%, according to economists polled by The Wall Street Journal.

To weather a trade war with the U.S., China is looking to its own consumers to keep the economy churning. Beijing has made bolstering domestic consumption a top policy priority for the first time, promising efforts to boost household spending. In one initiative this year, the government allocated 300 billion yuan, equivalent to around $42 billion, to expand a program that pays shoppers to trade in old vehicles or electronics for new ones.

Europe must maintain a steadfast commitment to open trade and bolster its legal and institutional foundations to raise the profile of the euro currency as confidence in the dominance of the U.S. dollar wanes, according to European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde.

President Trump on Monday said he was considering taking billions in grant money away from Harvard University and redistributing it to trade schools across the U.S.

President Trump posted on his Truth Social platform early on Memorial Day: "I am considering taking Three Billion Dollars of Grant Money away from a very antisemitic Harvard, and giving it to TRADE SCHOOLS all across our land".

Years before longtime Rep. Charlie Rangel became Harlem's longtime Democratic representative in Congress, he was an artillery specialist in the Korean War. In November 1950, near the North Korean village of Kunu-ri, the Chinese army encircled Rangel's unit. After being hit with shrapnel and leading dozens of soldiers to safety in a nighttime escape, Rangel was awarded a Purple Heart and a Bronze Star with valor.

The Air Force C-130 transport plane dipped down on the sun-baked airfield of this remote island in the northern Philippines, delivering a weapon system designed to give the U.S. an edge in the intensifying superpower standoff in the Pacific. The Navy-Marine Expeditionary Ship Interdiction System, or Nmesis, is an antiship missile launcher mounted on a remote-controlled truck. The dumbbell-shaped islet where it landed lies just 120 miles south of Taiwan.

title: La estrategia económica de Trump
content: Las acciones en materia económica del presidente estadounidense remecen los mercados. Además: una crisis medioambiental que une a México y EE. UU.
resumen:
La promesa del presidente Donald Trump es prosperidad económica para todos en Estados Unidos. En su segundo mandato, Trump ha emprendido medidas que han confundido y remecido a los mercados.

*   **Aranceles para los bienes importados:** Trump dijo que impondría un fuerte impuesto a las importaciones europeas y advirtió a Apple que los iPhones fabricados en el extranjero tendrían un arancel del 25 por ciento. Luego aplazó los aranceles a la Unión Europea hasta julio. Walmart anunció que las medidas arancelarias podrían obligarlos a subir los precios.
*   **Recortes y ajustes fiscales:** Los republicanos de la Cámara de Representantes aprobaron un proyecto de ley para promulgar la agenda fiscal de Trump, que podría sumar billones de dólares a la deuda federal.
*   **Acuerdos con todo el mundo:** Trump dedica parte de su diplomacia a lograr tratos comerciales. En su primera gira internacional de su segundo mandato, al Medio Oriente, ese fue el énfasis. Tras anunciarse tratos millonarios para vender chips a la región, algunos se preguntan si estará traicionando el futuro tecnológico de su país.

Los inversores ven una agenda que conlleva más deuda, mayores costos de financiamiento, inflación y una desaceleración económica.

**En cifras:**

*   189 millones: Los litros de aguas residuales sin tratar, productos químicos industriales y basura que fluyen por el río Tijuana desde Tijuana, México, hasta el sur de California.
*   1000: Los dólares que recibiría en una cuenta de inversión cada bebé recién nacido durante el mandato del presidente Trump de aprobarse un proyecto de ley.
*   Ocho: Los hombres que integran el grupo de migrantes que el gobierno de Estados Unidos intenta deportar a Sudán del Sur. Se cree que esos hombres proceden de países como Cuba, México y Vietnam.
*   148: El precio en dólares de un maxivestido “2 en 1” lanzado por la marca Lululemon.

title: Enviar dinero a casa será más caro: así afecta el nuevo impuesto sobre las remesas a los migrantes latinos en Estados Unidos
content: La medida del Gobierno de Trump, con un impuesto del 3,5 % a las remesas enviadas por migrantes sin estatus legal, afecta a millones de familias en ...
resumen:
El Gobierno de Trump implementó un impuesto del 3,5 % a las remesas enviadas por migrantes sin estatus legal.
La medida afecta a millones de familias en América Latina.
La Cámara de Representantes de Estados Unidos aprobó el impuesto a las remesas y ahora seguirá su curso legislativo en el Senado.
Por un envío de 1.000 dólares se tendría que pagar un extra de 35 dólares.
Los países que más podrían verse afectados son México (40% del dinero enviado desde Estados Unidos), Colombia, República Dominicana, Guatemala, Honduras y El Salvador.
Donald Trump propuso inicialmente un impuesto del 5%.
La presidente de México, Claudia Sheinbaum, y el mandatario de Colombia, Gustavo Petro, han mostrado su inconformidad con la medida.
Gustavo Petro advirtió que la decisión significaba "una reducción del salario real" de los trabajadores colombianos en Estados Unidos.
Colombia recibió en el año pasado el récord de 11.800 millones de dólares en remesas, la mayoría desde territorio estadounidense, según cifras del Banco de la República.
Sheinbaum sostuvo que se trata de un impuesto "discriminatorio" que "viola" un tratado fiscal firmado con Estados Unidos desde 1994.

title: Wall Street abre en verde tras el anuncio de Trump de un retraso en los aranceles a la Unión Europea
content: Trump anunció el domingo que pospone la fecha límite del arancel del 50% a la Unión Europea hasta el 9 de julio, a petición de Ursula von der Leyen, presidenta de la Comisión Europea.
resumen:
Wall Street abrió este martes en verde y su principal indicador, el Dow Jones, subía un 0,85% hasta los 41.957 puntos, después de que el presidente de EE. UU., Donald Trump anunciara que retrasa los aranceles del 50% a la Unión Europea (UE).

Diez minutos después del toque de campana, el selectivo S&P 500 crecía un 1,07% hasta los 5.865 enteros, y el tecnológico Nasdaq subía un 1,33% hasta situarse en 18.987 puntos.

Trump anunció el domingo que pospone la fecha límite del arancel del 50% a la Unión Europea hasta el 9 de julio, a petición de Ursula von der Leyen, presidenta de la Comisión Europea.

Esta semana los inversores seguirán de cerca los resultados de empresas como Nvidia, Macy’s y Costco. Entre los sectores reinaba el verde y las mayores ganancias eran para el tecnológico, con una subida de 1,56%.

Entre las 30 cotizadas del Dow Jones, la única bajada era para Salesforce (-0,64%); mientras que las ganancias eran para Nvidia (2,02%) y Nike (1,82%).

En el sector de la aviación comercial, destaca la subida de Southwest Airlines (3,26%), la cuarta del país, después de anunciar que va a comenzar a cobrar desde mañana por los equipajes facturados, a razón de 35 dólares el primero y 45 el segundo. Solo los miembros de la ‘tarjeta élite’ serán la excepción.

A esa hora, el petróleo de Texas perdía un 0,62% y se situaba por encima de la barrera de los 60 dólares, hasta los 61,15 dólares el barril.

title: Trump just re-declared trade war on the EU. Here's where his trade talks stand around the world.
content: President Donald Trump threatened a new tariff on the European Union on Friday. The 90-day pause on his "reciprocal tariffs" will run out on July 9. Trump has touted some initial deals ...
resumen:
President Donald Trump paused a larger trade war with the EU. His 90-day pause has two months remaining. Trump said he's in no hurry to sign a trade deal.

On May 23, Trump said he would impose a 50% tariff on the EU starting on June 1. He later told reporters he felt no need to cut a deal. By May 25, the president said he had agreed to the EU's request to pause the additional tariff until July 9.

Trump's 90-day pause on his "reciprocal tariffs" is also set to end July 9th.

European Union: Trump said on May 23 that discussions with the EU "are going nowhere!". Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent told Fox News, "the EU proposals have not been of the same quality that we've seen from our other important trading partners." As a result, Trump moved to impose the 50% tariff. Days later, the president said that talks had improved. US Trade Representative Jamieson Greer and EU Trade Commissioner Maroš Šefčovič are expected to meet in Paris next month.

China: US-China trade tensions have cooled considerably. On May 12, both sides announced a 90-day period where US tariffs were slashed from 145% to a base of 30%, while China cut its tariffs from 125% to 10%. The breakthrough came after Bessent and Greer held face-to-face talks with Vice Premier He Lifeng. Before the interim agreement, Trump had already softened the US stance by granting exemptions on iPhones, computers, and other electronics imported into the US from China.

Canada: Trump met with Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney in the Oval Office on May 7. During a public portion of their Oval Office meeting, Trump and Carney both said that there needs to be changes made to the US-Mexico-Canada agreement. The United States continues to impose a 25% tariff on non-USMCA-compliant Canadian goods and a 10% tariff on energy imported from Canada. Canada retaliated by imposing a 25% tariff on US goods.

United Kingdom: The White House announced an agreement with the UK on May 8. In the trade agreement, Trump will reverse tariffs on British steel and automobiles. British steel and aluminum won't be subject to US-imposed 25% tariffs. And tariffs for UK cars imported into the United States will be cut from 27.5% to 10% for the first 100,000 vehicles. US farmers will also get more access to UK markets. Trump's 10% tariff — still in effect for most countries — will remain in place for the UK.

India: Vice President JD Vance said on May 1 that a US-India trade deal would "be among the first deals" the administration will reach. Indian Commerce Minister Piyush Goyal recently traveled to the US. Trump announced a 27% tariff on Indian goods at the White House. His 90-day pause on those tariffs ends on July 9.

Vietnam: The US and Vietnam have held two rounds of trade talks, but a deal is still no quite done. Trump imposed a 46% tariff on Vietnam as part of his "Liberation Day" announcement — it, too, is subject to the 90-day pause.

Japan: Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba told reporters that he spoke with Trump directly. Japan and the US have held three rounds of talks thus far. Trump imposed a 24% tariff on Japanese goods before announcing his 90-day pause.

South Korea: South Korea sent representatives to the US early on, but it's unlikely to be one of the first countries to strike a deal. South Korea is holding snap elections on June 3.

title: Hallados en España 170 kilos de cocaína en catalizadores de automóviles llegados de Brasil
content: Alicante (España), 27 may (EFE).- La vigilancia aduanera española ha intervenido en Alicante (este) 170 kilos de cocaína ocultos en catalizadores de automóviles procedentes de Brasil, una operación ...
resumen: En Alicante (España), la vigilancia aduanera española intervino 170 kilos de cocaína ocultos en catalizadores de automóviles procedentes de Brasil. La operación terminó con dos detenidos acusados de delitos de contrabando, contra la salud pública y pertenencia a organización criminal. Las investigaciones comenzaron en 2023, detectando importaciones de catalizadores procedentes de Brasil con sospechas de droga escondida. Se centraron en una empresa implicada por incongruencias en su actividad económica, identificando a miembros de un presunto grupo criminal en Callosa del Segura (Alicante). Se descubrieron naves industriales como centro de distribución y un entramado empresarial alquilando instalaciones para importaciones. Se identificó a los administradores y socios de estas empresas como integrantes del grupo criminal, al servicio del responsable de la organización, en paradero desconocido en Sudamérica. A principios de abril de este año se detectó un contenedor llegado de Brasil con destino Alicante. Se verificó la existencia de cocaína oculta en los catalizadores. El valor de la cocaína incautada superaría los cinco millones de euros (5,7 millones de dólares) en el mercado negro.

title: China’s Soft Spot in Trade War With Trump: Risk of Huge Job Loss
content: A chronic housing slowdown and high youth unemployment rate have made China more vulnerable than it was in President Trump’s first term.
resumen:
President Trump, in his first term, claimed his tariffs led to the loss of five million jobs in China. In a 2019 tweet, he said his trade policies had put China “back on its heels.”

Four months into Mr. Trump’s second term, the United States and China are again negotiating over tariffs, and the Chinese labor market, especially factory jobs, is front and center.

A persistent property slowdown has wiped out jobs. New university graduates are pouring into the labor pool at a time when the unemployment rate among young workers is in the double digits.

Alicia Garcia-Herrero, chief economist for the Asia-Pacific region at the investment bank Natixis, said the importance of preserving China’s 100 million manufacturing jobs has grown.

Chinese and U.S. officials agreed to temporarily reduce the punishing tariffs they had imposed on each other.

Natixis said that if U.S. tariffs stayed at their current levels of at least 30 percent, exports to the United States would fall by half, resulting in a loss of up to six million manufacturing jobs. If the trade war resumes again in full, the job losses could surge to nine million.

China’s economy has struggled to recover from the pandemic, expanding more slowly than in the years of Mr. Trump’s first term, when growth was more than 6 percent a year. The Chinese government is targeting growth of around 5 percent this year, but many economists have predicted that the actual figure will not reach those levels.

In early 2018, China said its urban jobless rate had fallen to 15-year lows and the country had created a record number of new jobs.

Unemployment climbed especially among young people. The jobless rate among 16-to-24-year-olds was 15.8 percent in April. However, the figure is expected to surge again when 12 million new college graduates join the work force this year.

In 2023, when youth unemployment figures reached a record 21.3 percent, the Chinese government suspended the release of the figures. Beijing started distributing the figures again last year with a new methodology that lowered the jobless rate.

Fewer companies are offering full-time employment, turning instead to gig workers.

American industry is deeply dependent on rare earth metals and critical minerals controlled largely by China.

Diana Choyleva, chief economist at Enodo Economics, said China has an advantage in “trade war endurance.”

In April, before the United States and China agreed to suspend the heaviest tariffs, new export orders from China fell to their lowest level since 2022.

In Guangzhou, businesses had closed as orders from foreign buyers dropped before the ultrahigh tariffs were paused.

Jane Hu, an office worker in Shanghai, lost her job last month because of China’s countermeasure to raise duties on American imports to 125 percent. Her former employer, a construction equipment company, could not afford the tariffs. Sales declined about 40 percent, making layoffs unavoidable.

Yu Jiadong, a top official at China’s Ministry of Human Resources and Social Security, said the government had prepared a number of measures to keep employment stable, especially for Chinese exporters.

One factory owner in southern China said he had planned to lay off staff but held off when customers rushed to fill orders after the tariff truce. A government official had told him that if he needed to cut his work force, he should do so properly and quietly to avoid creating a stir.

Han Dongfang, the founder of China Labor Bulletin, said factory owners who employ salaried workers are required by law to compensate them in a layoff, usually paying one month’s salary for every year of employment.

Employment activity outside the manufacturing sector has contracted for more than two years.

Laura Wang, 23, a graduate student studying accounting in Chongqing, said that more than 80 percent of her classmates were struggling to find jobs.

title: Abinader dice RD sigue negociaciones con EE.UU. sobre aranceles aplicados por Trump

A ningún país a los que se le colocó el 10 % se le ha quitado ese arancel. Estados Unidos quiere tener una decisión general sobre los mismos.

title: Funcionarios y empresarios guatemaltecos piden a EE.UU. una rebaja en los aranceles
content: Ciudad de Guatemala, 27 may (EFE).- El Gobierno de Guatemala informó este martes que una comisión de "alto nivel" se encuentra en Estados Unidos para negociar una rebaja en el 10 % de aranceles ...
resumen: El Gobierno de Guatemala informó que una comisión de "alto nivel" se encuentra en Estados Unidos para negociar una rebaja en el 10 % de aranceles impuestos en abril pasado por el presidente Donald Trump. La delegación guatemalteca solicitó de manera formal en su primera reunión en Estados Unidos la rebaja de los aranceles en un encuentro con la Oficina de Representación Comercial de Estados Unidos, de acuerdo al Ministerio de Relaciones Exteriores. El Gobierno presentó el informe de acciones que da respuesta a las preocupaciones expresadas en el más reciente reporte de barreras comerciales, así como la carta de respaldo firmada por empresas guatemaltecas y estadounidenses que apoyan la solicitud de restablecer el acceso preferencial a productos de exportación de Guatemala. La comisión está encabezada por el ministro de Relaciones Exteriores, Carlos Martínez, y la ministra de Economía, Gabriela García. Los funcionarios están acompañados por "representantes del sector privado" guatemalteco. La delegación de la nación centroamericana tendrá alrededor de 20 reuniones "con asociaciones empresariales, agencias del Gobierno de EE.UU. y representantes del congreso estadounidense" en busca de reforzar las relaciones comerciales entre ambos países. El Gobierno estadounidense impuso un gravamen del 10 % a los productos procedentes de Guatemala. Durante los primeros tres meses del año, antes de la imposición de aranceles, el ingreso de divisas por las exportaciones guatemaltecas aumentó 10,7 %, en relación al mismo periodo del año pasado, liderado por productos como el café y los textiles, según las estadísticas oficiales en el inicio de mayo.

title: Illa desplegará un plan para consolidar Catalunya como "socio fiable" de Asia en plena guerra arancelaria de Trump
content: En pleno terremoto por la guerra arancelaria desencadenada por Donald Trump, el president de la Generalitat, Salvador Illa, considera que, sea cual sea el desenlace, Estados Unidos ya no es un socio f ...
resumen:
En plena guerra arancelaria, el president de la Generalitat, Salvador Illa, anunció desde Tokio que el Govern aprobará a finales de año el 'Plan Asia', una estrategia para convertir Catalunya en un "socio fiable y estable" de Asia, con foco en China e India.

El Executiu considera que Catalunya debe aprovechar el potencial de Asia, que concentra el 60% de la población mundial y se estima que hacia 2030 aportará más de la mitad del crecimiento global.

El objetivo es "reorganizar" y "reforzar" la presencia de Catalunya en Asia, siguiendo la estrategia del presidente del Gobierno, Pedro Sánchez.

Catalunya ya tiene un 'Plan Japón' desde 2009 y delegaciones en Tokio y Seúl, así como oficinas de promoción económica en Pekín, Seúl, Tokio y Bombay, además de acuerdos institucionales.

Se analizará reforzar la red de oficinas de Acció.

El Govern busca tejer vínculos con instituciones asiáticas en sectores como el tecnológico y el científico, y promover el intercambio académico y de investigación.

Illa se reunió con el vicepresidente ejecutivo de NTT Data, Masanori Suzuki, y con siete multinacionales niponas, incluyendo Fujitsu y Mitsubishi.

Illa se reunió con 835 catalanes que viven en Japón.

title: Ganancias del grupo propietario de Temu sufrieron una caída del 47% en el primer trimestre
content: El grupo chino PDD Holdings, matriz de la plataforma de comercio electrónico Temu, obtuvo un beneficio neto atribuido de 14.742 millones de yuanes (1.799 millones de euros) al cierre del primer ...
resumen:
El grupo chino PDD Holdings, matriz de la plataforma de comercio electrónico Temu, obtuvo un beneficio neto atribuido de 14.742 millones de yuanes (1.799 millones de euros) al cierre del primer trimestre de 2025, lo que representa una caída del 47% en comparación con el resultado contabilizado en el mismo periodo del año anterior.

Los ingresos del grupo chino, que no desglosa la evolución del negocio de Temu, sumaron 95.672 millones de yuanes (11.677 millones de euros), un 10% más que entre enero y marzo del año anterior.

La facturación de PDD Holdings en el negocio de servicios de marketing online aumentó un 14,7%, hasta 48.722 millones de yuanes (5.947 millones de euros), mientras que los ingresos por servicios de transacciones subieron un 5,8%, hasta 46.950 millones de yuanes (5.730 millones de euros).

Lei Chen, presidente y co-consejero delegado de PDD Holdings, afirmó que en el primer trimestre, se realizaron inversiones sustanciales en el ecosistema de plataforma para apoyar a comerciantes y consumidores ante los rápidos cambios del entorno externo, lo que afectó la rentabilidad a corto plazo, pero reforzará la solidez de la plataforma a largo plazo.

Jiazhen Zhao, co-consejero delegado de PDD Holdings, afirmó que un mayor apoyo a los comerciantes es esencial para construir un ecosistema comercial sólido que pueda ofrecer experiencias de compra satisfactorias a los consumidores.

La compañía prevé una desaceleración del crecimiento a medida que surjan nuevos desafíos, lo que se ha visto “aún más acelerado por los cambios en el entorno externo durante el primer trimestre”, declaró Jun Liu, vicepresidenta de Finanzas de PDD Holdings.

Lei Chen subrayó que, “en un entorno externo que cambia rápidamente, nuestro negocio global está colaborando con vendedores de diversas regiones para ofrecer precios estables y un suministro abundante a los consumidores de todo el mundo”.

El grupo chino PDD Holdings, matriz de la plataforma de comercio electrónico Temu, obtuvo un beneficio neto atribuido de 14.742 millones de yuanes.

title: Friedrich Merz se opone a la semana laboral de cuatro días
content: El canciller de Alemania, Friedrich Merz, se pronunció en contra de la idea de introducir una semana laboral de cuatro días en el país. 'Los alemanes necesitan ...
resumen: El canciller de Alemania, Friedrich Merz, se pronunció en contra de la idea de introducir una semana laboral de cuatro días en el país. "Los alemanes necesitan trabajar más. Con una semana laboral de cuatro días y un equilibrio entre trabajo y vida personal, no podemos sostener la prosperidad de este país", sostuvo Merz durante su intervención en la conferencia del Consejo Económico de la Unión Demócrata Cristiana, en Berlín. Datos de la Organización para la Cooperación y el Desarrollo Económico (OCDE) muestran que de sus treinta y ocho países miembros, Alemania es donde menos horas se trabaja en promedio. Los expertos pronostican que la economía alemana se contraerá un 0,2% este año y que entrará en recesión por tercer año consecutivo. A fines de 2023 se aplicó por seis meses la semana laboral de cuatro días en 45 compañías alemanas. El experimento mostró una mejora en la satisfacción de los empleados. Un 50% reportó un bienestar significativamente mayor, muchos durmieron 38 minutos más por semana, hicieron más ejercicio y experimentaron menos estrés. Esto ayudó a incrementar unos 8 puntos el nivel de retención del personal.

title: El animal que Estados Unidos lava con cloro antes de venderlo en supermercados: por qué es importante en las negociaciones con Europa
content: Emilio González, economista, señala en La Linterna uno de los puntos clave de la tensión por los aranceles y que tiene que ver con el sector alimentario ...
resumen: El lavado de pollo con soluciones cloradas, práctica habitual en Estados Unidos pero prohibida en la UE desde 1997, ha vuelto al centro de la guerra comercial entre ambos bloques. Donald Trump amenaza con aranceles del 50% a productos europeos. El economista Emilio González, profesor de la Universidad Nebrija, alerta en La Linterna de COPE sobre la estrategia estadounidense: "Trump usa estos conflictos para debilitar al adversario y obtener concesiones, pero detrás hay un choque de filosofías: ellos priorizan la desinfección final; Europa, la prevención desde la granja". La Unión Europea defiende su veto por riesgos sanitarios y ambientales, Washington insiste en que es una medida "proteccionista". El proceso, denominado Tratamiento de Reducción de Patógenos, implica sumergir las canales de pollo en agua con compuestos clorados (hipoclorito de sodio, dióxido de cloro) tras el sacrificio. Su objetivo declarado es eliminar bacterias como Salmonella o E. coli. Según el Consejo Nacional del Pollo de EE.UU., "es seguro, no altera el sabor y reduce enfermedades". La Agencia Europea de Seguridad Alimentaria (EFSA) lo rechaza: "El cloro enmascara la suciedad acumulada en granjas industriales, donde los pollos viven hacinados entre heces y amoníaco". Un informe de 2008 añade que puede generar subproductos cancerígenos como cloratos, persistentes en el organismo. La FDA y USDA (Estados Unidos) aprueban concentraciones de hasta 60 ppm de cloro, considerándolo inocuo, la Comisión Europea establece un límite de 0.01 mg/kg de clorato en alimentos, alertando de daños en la tiroides infantil. Consumer Reports (2014) detectó bacterias en el 97% de muestras de pollo estadounidense, pese al cloro. El 50% contenía materia fecal, mientras que la Universidad de Southampton reflejó en 2018 que el cloro pone bacterias en "modo hibernación", haciéndolas indetectables en laboratorio pero activas al consumirse. Emilio González lo resume: "Es un parche químico para un sistema productivo insalubre. Europa exige vacunación y espacios limpios; EE.UU. prefiere soluciones baratas al final". Estados Unidos exportó el 16.5% de su producción avícola en 2016, principalmente a México, Canadá y Cuba, y Trump busca romper el veto europeo para ampliar mercados. Trump necesita éxitos comerciales para compensar su caída en las encuestas. Monique Goyens, de la Organización Europea de Consumidores: "No tememos al cloro, sino a que sea un pretexto para ocultar prácticas inhumanas".

title: Trade crime is soaring, US firms say, as Trump’s tariffs incentivize fraud
content: As President Trump’s tariffs have ratcheted up in recent months, so have the mysterious solicitations some US companies have received, offering them ways to avoid the taxes. Shipping companies, many ...
resumen: As President Trump’s tariffs have increased, so have the solicitations some US companies have received, offering ways to avoid the taxes. Shipping companies, many of them based in China, have reached out to US firms that import apparel, auto parts, and jewelry, offering solutions that they say can make the tariffs go away. The proposals reflect a new flood of fraudulent activity, according to company executives and government officials. As US tariffs on foreign products have increased dramatically, so have the incentives for companies to find ways around them. The Chinese firms advertising these services describe their methods as valid solutions. For a fee, they find ways to bring products to the United States with much lower tariffs. Experts say these practices are methods of customs fraud. The companies may be dodging tariffs by altering the information about the shipments that is given to the US government to qualify for a lower tariff rate, or they may physically move the goods to another country that is subject to a lower tariff before shipping them to the United States, a technique known as transshipment. The Trump administration said this month that it would focus more on fighting trade fraud, including tariff evasion. The administration is also trying to convince other countries to step up their own enforcement efforts, including in trade talks with Vietnam, Mexico, and Malaysia. Many US companies say the scale of illicit activity now far outweighs the ability of these governments to thwart it.

title: Will Trump's tariffs on China raise prices at Ross? CEO says maybe. Here's what to know
content: Ross said President Donald Trump's tariffs could impact its profitability this year, potentially leading to price hikes. Find out more.
resumen:
Ross withdrew its fiscal 2025 forecasts on May 22, saying President Donald Trump's tariffs could impact its profits this year, according to Reuters.

The store said more than half its goods are made in China, which could lead it to potentially raising some of its prices if "inflationary pressures persist in the retail industry."

Ross' Chief Executive Officer Jim Conroy said the tariffs are expected to reduce earnings per share by 11-16 cents in the second quarter, according to the Wall Street Journal.

The Trump administration and China reached an agreement on May 12 to slash tariffs for the next 90 days while the two sides negotiate a long-term deal. This comes just weeks after the president raised more than 100% tariffs on China in a "tit-for-tat" reciprocal tariff battle originally intended to shift focus to American-made products.

Under the temporary new deal, Trump lowered the 125% reciprocal tariffs imposed on Chinese imports to just 10%. Trump's 20% tariff on Chinese fentanyl products will remain, meaning the U.S. tariffs on China will total 30% overall.

The deal does not apply to the universal 25% tariffs the president imposed on automobiles, auto parts, steel and aluminum.

Trump said he would raise the tariffs against China again if it does not agree to a final resolution after 90 days, but not back to the previous level of 145%.

title: Trump said his tariffs would ‘NEVER CHANGE’. Here’s a list of the times they changed.
content: Crikey does its best to keep up with the changes to policies that Trump said, in all caps, would 'NEVER CHANGE'.
resumen:
US President Donald Trump announced this week that the implementation of a 50% tariff on goods from the European Union would be delayed from its initially proposed start of June 1 until July 9 to allow for negotiations with the bloc.

February 1, 2025: US President Donald Trump signs three executive orders imposing 25% tariffs on all goods from Mexico and Canada (with some exceptions for Canada subject to a 10% tariff) and a 10% tariff on imports from China, to be imposed from February 4.

February 3: Trump agrees to a one-month pause on tariffs with the leaders of Mexico and Canada.

March 4: US tariffs on imports from Canada, China, and Mexico come into effect.

March 7: Trump once again delays tariffs on goods from Canada and Mexico.

March 26: The White House announces a series of tariffs on foreign-made cars and foreign car parts.

March 31: White House Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt insists there will be “no exemptions at this time” to the impending tariffs.

April 2: Trump announces “reciprocal tariffs” on all of the USA’s trading partners. This includes Australia, as well as the Heard and McDonald Islands, uninhabited Australian external territories that are home to our only active volcanoes.

April 4: Trump posts to Truth Social: “TO THE MANY INVESTORS COMING INTO THE UNITED STATES AND INVESTING MASSIVE AMOUNTS OF MONEY, MY POLICIES WILL NEVER CHANGE.”

April 8: In response to retaliatory tariffs from China, the White House announces an additional 50% tariff levied on top of previously imposed tariffs of 20% and 34%, bringing the total tariff on Chinese goods to 104%.

April 9: Trump announces he will pause the harshest of his tariffs for 90 days. A baseline tariff of 10% stays in place for most nations, and tariffs on China remain.

April 11: Trump confirms that tariffs on China will now be 145%.

April 14: Trump announces that he is considering a temporary exemption for automakers from the tariffs he’d previously imposed. “I don’t change my mind, but I’m flexible,” he tells reporters.

April 22: Trump says American tariffs on Chinese imports will come down “substantially”. “It won’t be that high, not going to be that high,” he tells an Oval Office press conference.

May 12: Trump agrees to a three-month cut on US tariffs on Chinese goods, down 115 percentage points to 30%. China drops its tariffs on US goods to 10%.

May 23: On the same day he proposes a 50% tariff on the EU, Trump threatens a 25% tariff on Apple’s iPhone unless the company brings its manufacturing jobs to the US.

May 25: Trump announces a pause on the proposed EU tariffs. The threat of tariffs on Apple, for now, remains.

title: Trade Crime Is Soaring, U.S. Firms Say, as Trump’s Tariffs Incentivize Fraud
content: President Trump’s steep global tariffs have supercharged efforts to evade them. Some U.S. companies say the government is ill equipped to keep up.
resumen: U.S. companies are receiving solicitations offering ways to avoid tariffs, with shipping companies, many based in China, offering solutions to U.S. firms that import apparel, auto parts, and jewelry. These proposals reflect a new flood of fraudulent activity, as U.S. tariffs on foreign products have increased sharply. Chinese firms describe their methods as valid solutions, but experts say these practices are methods of customs fraud, such as altering shipment information or moving goods to countries with lower tariffs (transshipment). The Trump administration said it would focus more on fighting trade fraud, but many American companies say the scale of illicit activity outweighs the government's ability to thwart it. These schemes are costing the U.S. government billions of dollars in tariff revenue annually. David Rashid, the executive chairman of Plews, said that unfairly traded products had filtered into supply chains throughout the United States. As Mr. Trump has raised tariffs to levels not seen in a century, companies say customs fraud is also reaching new heights. In his first months in office, Mr. Trump put a 10 percent tariff on most products globally, as well as a 25 percent tariff on steel, aluminum, and cars. Leslie Jordan, an apparel manufacturer, said fraudulent schemes were becoming "rampant" in her industry. Kush Desai, a White House spokesman, said that "instead of trying to find illegal workarounds to tariffs, foreign exporters would be better off telling their governments to negotiate a trade deal with the United States." John Foote, a customs lawyer at Kelley Drye & Warren, described the uptick in fraud as "a sign of entering a high tariff era." The U.S. government charges tariffs based on the item, its declared dollar value, and its country of origin. Schemes to evade tariffs include reporting a lower value for a product, misclassifying the item, and sending products to another country before they go to the United States. In April, Chinese exports to the United States fell 21 percent from a year earlier, but Chinese exports to Southeast Asian countries rose by the same percentage. An analysis by Exiger found that more than 3,000 companies in Mexico depended on Chinese shipments for 75 percent or more of their supply chain. Chinese companies are also marketing a method, "delivered duty paid," or D.D.P., that ostensibly reduces the U.S. importers’ legal liability for tariff fraud. Christopher Carney, an auto industry executive, said companies offering these schemes were operating with "a sense of impunity." The Department of Justice said trade and customs fraud would be a new priority under the Trump administration. Brad Muller, the vice president of marketing and government affairs at Charlotte Pipe and Foundry, said that the U.S. government was unable to stop Chinese companies from transshipping their products. Trish Driscoll, a spokeswoman for Customs and Border Protection, said that the department used enforcement tools, intelligence, and partnerships to combat tariff evasion, and, as a result of recent presidential actions, was now imposing the most severe penalties permitted by law. During the week of May 5 through May 9, Customs and Border Protection took in more than $630 million by reviewing more than 2,000 shipments detected for duty evasion. Importers are urging Congress to give the government more resources to go after fraud.

title: Según la Licencia 41B la autorización petrolera a Chevron en Venezuela ya expiró; hay expectativa sobre una nueva licencia de operación mínima
content: Según versiones de medios, la nueva licencia permitiría solo actividades esenciales de mantenimiento y prohibiría nuevas inversiones y la exportación de ...
resumen: Según la Licencia 41B, la autorización a Chevron para realizar actividades petroleras en Venezuela expiró la madrugada del martes 27 de mayo. El gobierno de Estados Unidos no se ha pronunciado públicamente sobre una nueva prórroga o extensión. Versiones aseguran que el Gobierno de Estados Unidos se prepara para conceder a Chevron una nueva licencia de actividad mínima en Venezuela. La licencia permitiría solo actividades esenciales de mantenimiento y prohibiría nuevas inversiones y la exportación de crudo. La decisión de no renovar la licencia de Chevron en Venezuela, bajo condiciones previas, representaría un golpe significativo para el régimen venezolano. Marco Rubio anunció que el gobierno no renovaría la licencia de operación de Chevron en Venezuela. La licencia petrolera pro-Maduro - Biden en Venezuela vencerá según lo programado el próximo martes 27 de mayo, comunicó Rubio. Los congresistas de origen cubano María Elvira Salazar, Carlos Antonio Giménez y Mario Diaz-Balart parecen haber influido en la decisión del gobierno estadounidense.
