title: Luis Almagro alerta que América Latina sufrirá "un desastre económico" si Estados Unidos lo fuerza romper lazos con China
content: El exsecretario general de la OEA, Luis Almagro, advirtió que cortar el comercio de América Latina con China, como presiona Estados Unidos, podría provocar una grave crisis regional debido a la alta d ...
resumen: Luis Almagro, exsecretario general de la OEA, advirtió que cortar el comercio de América Latina con China, como presiona Estados Unidos, podría provocar una grave crisis regional debido a la alta dependencia económica de la región con Pekín. El comercio de América Latina con China alcanzó en 2024 un récord de 518.470 millones de dólares, según datos del Ministerio de Comercio de China. Para Luis Almagro, eliminar esa conexión comercial bajo presión de Estados Unidos sería “un desastre económico regional muy violento”. Almagro alertó que prácticamente todos los países de América Latina dependen de sus vínculos con China, que se ha convertido en el primer o segundo socio comercial de la mayoría. La creciente presión de Washington, intensificada bajo el segundo mandato de Donald Trump, representa un riesgo directo para las economías latinoamericanas. Almagro advierte que suspender comercio con China desencadenaría un “desastre económico” en América Latina. Durante su gestión en la Organización de los Estados Americanos, Almagro denunció las tensiones geopolíticas que obligan a la región a elegir entre China y Estados Unidos. Las inversiones chinas en Latinoamérica sumaron 14.710 millones de dólares en 2024, y se formalizaron acuerdos como la adhesión de Colombia a la Franja y la Ruta. En total, 37.000 empresas latinoamericanas operan actualmente en territorio chino. Estados Unidos ha utilizado una diplomacia coercitiva para frenar la expansión china en América Latina. El politólogo Zhou Zhiwei, de la Academia China de Ciencias Sociales, afirmó que estas acciones de Washington vulneran el principio internacional del derecho a establecer relaciones comerciales con terceros países.

title: Asistencia de Chile a cumbre de BRICS
content: Los intereses estratégicos del país aconsejan mirar con distancia la posibilidad de buscar por el momento algún tipo de asociación con este bloque.
resumen: El Presidente Boric confirmó que asistirá a la cumbre de los BRICS el próximo 6 de julio en Rio de Janeiro, respondiendo a una invitación del Presidente de Brasil. La concurrencia del Mandatario ha reabierto el debate sobre la pertinencia de que Chile se integre a dicho acuerdo, creado en 2010 por Brasil, Rusia, China e India -al que luego se sumó Sudáfrica- como un espacio de asociación alternativo. Sectores del Frente Amplio y del Partido Comunista han insistido en la conveniencia de que Chile se asocie al bloque. Los BRICS no constituyen un acuerdo comercial, pero hay quienes ven que este espacio -que ya concentra el 45% de la población mundial, y un PIB combinado de US$ 28 mil billones- puede ser una instancia que favorezca futuras inversiones, y eventualmente acceder a las facilidades que provee el Nuevo Banco del Desarrollo, creado a instancias de los BRICS. Sería la posibilidad de diversificar los intereses estratégicos del país y participar de instancias de gobernanza global. Los intereses estratégicos del país aconsejan mirar con distancia la posibilidad de buscar por el momento algún tipo de asociación con el BRICS. Los países ejes de dicho bloque son China y Rusia, los que por distintas razones se encuentran hoy en el eje de controversias globales. China está sumida en una guerra comercial con Estados Unidos. Rusia es responsable por la invasión a Ucrania. Un acercamiento a los BRICS en estos momentos podría dar a entender que hay intenciones de profundizar el acercamiento con el gobierno chino, lo que puede ser complejo en medio de la guerra comercial con Estados Unidos y cuando Chile está en pleno proceso de negociación de su propia situación arancelaria con la administración Trump. Chile ya tiene importantes acuerdos comerciales con China, Brasil e India. Desde la Cancillería se ha indicado que no está todavía en evaluación la posibilidad de incorporarse al BRICS.

title: El ‘efecto Trump’ impacta resultados electorales a nivel mundial, partidos de derecha son los grandes perdedores
content: De hecho, un informe reciente de la Fundación para la Alianza Democrática sostiene que desde que regresó Trump a la Casa Blanca la popularidad de Estados Unidos a nivel mundial ha caído de manera ...
resumen:
El ‘efecto Trump’ impacta resultados electorales a nivel mundial, partidos de derecha son los grandes perdedores.

El triunfo de Donald Trump en las elecciones presidenciales de Estados Unidos a finales de 2024 fue visto como un tanque de oxígeno para otros movimientos de corte conservador alrededor del mundo.

A seis meses de su victoria, en lugar de fortalecer a los partidos de derecha o conservadores, la retórica de Donald Trump y algunas de sus políticas han terminado dando impulso a liberales y centristas en diversas naciones, fenómeno que los expertos ya llaman el “efecto Trump” o el “abrazo del oso”.

En lo corrido del año van por lo menos cinco procesos electorales en los que la influencia de Trump ha terminado hundiendo o debilitando las aspiraciones de partidos de derecha.

El tema que más ha influido en la tendencia fue la decisión, tomada a comienzos de abril, de imponer aranceles unilaterales a las exportaciones de distintos países. También lo ha sido su acercamiento con Rusia, así como los comentarios hostiles relacionados con una supuesta intención de anexión de Groenlandia, el Canal de Panamá, la Franja de Gaza y Canadá.

Un informe reciente de la Fundación para la Alianza Democrática sostiene que desde que regresó Trump a la Casa Blanca la popularidad de Estados Unidos a nivel mundial ha caído de manera dramática: de una valoración positiva de 22 por ciento en 2024 pasó a una negativa del menos 5 por ciento el mes pasado.

El último ejemplo se presentó este pasado domingo durante las elecciones presidenciales en Rumania donde el centrista Nicusor Dan derrotó al nacionalista George Simion, un admirador declarado de Trump. Dan se impuso con un 53 por ciento del voto vs a al 46 por ciento de su rival.

El caso más emblemático del ‘efecto Trump’ es el de Canadá. El primer ministro Justin Trudeau tuvo que renunciar y convocar a elecciones anticipadas. El partido conservador los aventajaba por más de 10 puntos en las encuestas, pero se anotaron una victoria bajo el liderazgo de Mark Carney. La imposición de aranceles del 25 por ciento por parte de Trump y sus amenazas de anexar Canadá como el 51.º estado provocaron una oleada de patriotismo entre los canadienses que Carney capitalizó presentándose como el defensor de la soberanía canadiense frente a las agresiones de Trump.

En Australia, el primer ministro Anthony Albanese y su Partido Laborista -liberales- también aseguraron un segundo mandato. El líder de la oposición, Peter Dutton, adoptó posturas similares a las de Trump, incluyendo promesas de reducir programas de diversidad e inclusión. La imposición de aranceles por parte de Trump y su retórica agresiva disminuyeron la confianza de los australianos en Estados Unidos, beneficiando a Albanese en las urnas.

En Alemania, pese a que la coalición conservadora liderada por Friedrich Merz se impuso en las elecciones federales de febrero pasado, el “efecto Trump” también pesó. El respaldo del mandatario republicano y aliados suyos al partido Alternativa para Alemania (AfD), terminó limitando el avance de la extrema derecha. Merz ha comenzado a ganar espacios abogando por una mayor independencia europea respecto a Estados Unidos, especialmente en defensa y política exterior, en respuesta precisamente a las políticas de Trump.

En marzo también hubo elecciones en Groenlandia, que terminó ganando el Partido Democrático -centroderecha- bajo el liderazgo de Jens-Frederik Nielsen. Nielsen ha calificado al presidente republicano como “una amenaza para nuestra independencia”.

El “efecto Trump” puede influir en las elecciones presidenciales de Corea del Sur, previstas para junio, y las de Japón. En el caso surcoreano, los aranceles impuestos por Trump al país estarían impulsando al candidato progresista Lee Jae-myung, que actualmente lidera las encuestas. En Japón, la suerte del primer ministro Shigeru Ishiba y su partido -el PLD- también pasan por Trump. Los analistas prevén que la suerte del PLD dependerá de las negociaciones que adelanta el país con la administración republicana en torno a un acuerdo comercial.

title: Trump aplaza al 9 de julio la subida del 50% en los aranceles a vinos y bebidas alcohólicas europeas
content: El sector vinícola europeo respira temporalmente, pero teme el impacto económico si no se alcanza un acuerdo antes de julio de 2025 ...
resumen: El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, anunció el domingo 25 de mayo que retrasa hasta el 9 de julio de 2025 la aplicación del arancel del 50% sobre productos procedentes de la Unión Europea, entre ellos el vino y las bebidas alcohólicas. Esta decisión llegó tras una llamada telefónica con la presidenta de la Comisión Europea, Ursula von der Leyen, quien solicitó más tiempo para avanzar en las negociaciones comerciales en curso. Trump comunicó el aplazamiento a través de su plataforma Truth Social, donde indicó que accedía a la prórroga a petición directa de Von der Leyen. La medida anunciada en mayo por Trump forma parte de una estrategia más amplia de presión comercial contra la Unión Europea, en la que también figuran otras tarifas: un arancel del 25% sobre coches y piezas procedentes de Europa, en vigor desde abril, y una tarifa general del 10% aplicada desde el pasado mes. Estados Unidos representa uno de los principales destinos para las exportaciones europeas de vino, en especial para países como Francia, Italia y España. Según los últimos datos de la Organización Internacional de la Viña y el Vino (OIV), más del 60% de los vinos importados en Estados Unidos durante 2024 fueron de origen europeo. En el caso español, el valor total de las exportaciones vinícolas al mercado estadounidense superó los 900 millones de euros el año pasado. La Federación Española del Vino (FEV) y la Interprofesional del Vino (OIVE) han expresado su preocupación ante la posibilidad de que el nuevo arancel se haga efectivo en julio. La amenaza también alcanza a otras bebidas alcohólicas europeas. La Comisión Europea sigue apostando por una solución pactada que permita evitar esta escalada y mantiene activa su propuesta de represalias comerciales por un valor cercano a los 100.000 millones de euros si Washington no retira los aranceles. En 2019, Washington impuso un arancel del 25% sobre varios productos del sector como represalia por los subsidios europeos a Airbus.

title: El dólar
content: Luego, avancé en otro artículo sobre el nuevo mundo desglobalizado y la próxima recesión como consecuencia del choque de oferta de insumos y productos chinos, en los Estados Unidos, a raíz de la ...
resumen: El autor ha escrito sobre el nuevo orden monetario internacional y el debilitamiento del dólar, iniciado por Trump en enero de 2025. Inicialmente, se esperaba una recesión debido al choque de oferta de insumos chinos, pero el escenario cambió. El 12 de mayo, la Casa Blanca anunció negociaciones con China para reducir tarifas y mantener un arancel básico, con el objetivo de mejorar el comercio bilateral. Trump implementó un impuesto del 3,5% a las remesas de migrantes indocumentados enviadas desde Estados Unidos, lo que afectará a países como Nicaragua, Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras y México. Se espera que esta medida genere USD 12.000 millones adicionales en recaudación. El presupuesto de 2026 planea recortes de impuestos, lo que aumentará el déficit fiscal. El economista Kenneth Rogoff, en su libro "Nuestro dólar, vuestro problema", argumenta que la sobrevaloración del dólar perjudica la competitividad estadounidense. El déficit de Estados Unidos estimula altas tasas de interés, encareciendo el dólar en países emergentes. Brasil elevó el impuesto sobre operaciones financieras, y Argentina implementó una medida para que las personas puedan sacar hasta USD 50.000 mensuales de sus ahorros dolarizados sin justificación. En Paraguay, el BCP inyectó USD 579 millones a abril para mitigar el valor del dólar. El gran tema es el déficit comercial de bienes de Estados Unidos versus China, que está cerca de USD 295.000 millones.

title: Tariffs, inflation worries loom. Lansing developments churning along for now
content: Building costs rose in the first quarter of 2025 by more than any four-month period in 2024, one cost index found.
resumen: The 25% steel and aluminum tariffs imposed by the Trump administration are expected to increase building costs. Uncertainty surrounding tariffs, inflation and the economy puts future projects "at higher risk," an economist said. Grand Avenue in downtown Lansing, for the next couple years at least, will be the center of much of the area's most significant new developments. Construction crews have broken ground on a new Lansing City Hall and affordable housing complex across the street from the Capital Area Transportation Authority's bus station. A 28-story skyscraper just a few blocks north is expected to become the city's tallest building when work is done in about two years. President Donald Trump's 25% tariffs on steel and aluminum imports took effect in March. In April, Trump's trade war ramped up with more announced tariffs before he paused some and increased those targeting China. The tariff announcements, last-minute changes and uncertainty have resulted in stock market drops and worries about continued inflation. Cristina Benton, a senior consultant with the East Lansing-based Anderson Economic Group, said steel and aluminum are fundamental components of the construction materials and there's also a 14.5% tariff in place for lumber for Canada and various appliances and fixtures made in countries around the world. Paul Gentilozzi, owner of Gentilozzi Real Estate, said steel costs for the New Vision Lansing project, the 28-story skyscraper that will have apartments and business, have already increased by $400,000, to $2.4 million. He's estimating a $2.5 million increase in costs over the next 18 months due to a combination of tariffs and price increases. Projects that have started are likely to continue because contracts with general contractors and vendors have already been signed, Benton said. Developer Pat Gillespie, whose company is involved in the Spartan Gateway District project at Michigan State University and will redevelop the former Sears site at Frandor, said he hasn't yet felt the impact of tariffs but has no reason to believe they will put the brakes on impending projects in the Lansing area. The Turner Construction Company, an international construction firm with an office in Michigan, releases a Turner Building Cost Index each quarter. The index reported a 1.18% increase in building costs in the first quarter of 2025. Gentilozzi isn't just keeping an eye on tariffs and inflation in an effort to keep costs low. A $400,000 a month interest payment during a build can be common. Gentilozzi said the New Vision building will have post-tensioned concrete for walls, floors and columns. The concrete has steel cables that run through them and are tightened as the concrete dries. Those cables are made in the Ukraine and take six months to produce, plus another month on a ship. Gillespie agreed that interest rates are probably a bigger issue than tariffs. Rising construction costs − whether caused by tariffs or other factors − may ultimately affect the size and design of buildings and even rental prices, Gillespie said.

title: Estado de los ESTADOS
content: Somos una agencia de información y análisis conformada por un equipo de profesionales, cuyo objetivo es la creación y difusión de contenidos ...
resumen:
El texto aborda varios temas:

*   **Reforma Judicial:** Se critica el proceso de la reforma judicial, señalando la falta de requisitos de capacidad y experiencia para los candidatos, así como la injerencia de funcionarios en la promoción del voto. Se menciona la necesidad de una reforma judicial, pero se cuestiona la actual.
*   **CNTE:** Se analiza la relación entre la CNTE y el gobierno, destacando su influencia y el diálogo con el titular de Educación, Mario Delgado, y la secretaria de Gobernación. Se menciona que la CNTE fue un brazo armado para López Obrador.
*   **Economía:** Se discute la desaceleración económica, la reducción de la tasa de interés por parte del Banxico, y las proyecciones de contracción del PIB por parte del FMI y el Banco Mundial. Se menciona la vulnerabilidad de México a los aranceles de EE. UU.
*   **Otros temas:** Se plantean preguntas sobre la participación de expresidentes en la votación, el costo de la gasolina, y otros temas como la posible renuncia de Salinas Pliego y el cierre de la Facultad de Homeopatía.
*   **Citas:** Se cita a Julio Anguita: “Quien vota por los corruptos los legitima, los justifica. y es tan responsable como ellos”.
*   **Fechas:** El texto está fechado el 27 de mayo de 2025.

resumen: Nvidia faces major risks from escalating US-China trade tensions, with Chinese competitors rapidly gaining market share and threatening Nvidiaâs international growth prospects. The companyâ99s premium pricing and high valuation multiples are unsustainable as the GPU market shifts toward total cost of ownership and lower-cost alternatives. Recent margin compression and negative EPS revisions signal that Nvidiaâs forward growth will likely underperform, justifying a strong sell rating ahead of earnings. Shares of GPU giant NVIDIA (NASDAQ:NVDA) (TSX:NVDA:CA) are down roughly 3.5% in the last six months and more than 2% year-to-date. This article was written by Noah's Arc Capital Management. title: "Vamos a seguir luchando para que se elimine ese 10 %", dice Abinader sobre arancel de EE. UU.
content: El presidente informó que el Gobierno se encuentra en conversaciones constantes con la administración de TrumpDijo que el Gobierno analiza el posible impacto de un impuesto a las remesas ...
resumen:
El presidente Luis Abinader informó que el Gobierno se encuentra en "contacto permanente" con la administración del presidente Donald Trump para tratar de lograr la eliminación del arancel del 10 % que actualmente se aplica a productos dominicanos que ingresan a Estados Unidos.

Abinader señaló que República Dominicana fue uno de los primeros países en solicitar una reunión formal sobre el tema.

El mandatario expresó: "Nosotros vamos a seguir luchando para que se elimine ese 10 %".

El presidente explicó que, aunque en algunos casos se ha hablado de una reducción, esto debe entenderse en el contexto de otros aranceles mucho más altos aplicados a países como China, donde se redujo de un 120 % a un 40 %.

Además, aclaró que, hasta ahora, a ningún país que tenía un arancel del 10 % se le ha exonerado completamente de esa carga.

Abinader dijo que sigue de cerca el avance en Estados Unidos sobre el nuevo impuesto del 3.5 % a las remesas, aprobado recientemente en la Cámara de Representantes como parte del plan fiscal impulsado por Trump.

La medida, que aún debe ser debatida en el Senado, ha generado preocupación en países que dependen de estos envíos, como República Dominicana.

"Estamos en contacto permanente con la administración del presidente Trump, tanto para el tema de las tarifas como para ese nuevo tema de las remesas, que es relativamente reciente, de las últimas tres semanas", explicó Abinader.

Dijo que aún se están evaluando los detalles del impuesto, ya que "en una parte dice que es para los inmigrantes ilegales", y consideró que su implementación sería de difícil cobro.

"Estamos trabajando con ellos (el gobierno de EE. UU.) en ese sentido, igual que otros países de Centroamérica", aseguró el mandatario.

title: Misinformation casts shadow on US-China trade truce
content: US President Donald Trump’s on-again, off-again tariffs have sent jitters through the world economy. Read more at straitstimes.com. Read more at straitstimes.com.
resumen: A tide of misinformation is casting a shadow over a temporary trade truce between Washington and Beijing. The world’s two biggest economies agreed earlier in May to pause reciprocal tariffs for 90 days. An alternate reality is unfolding across social media platforms, including China’s Douyin and Weibo, where a surge of falsehoods fuelling anti-American sentiment could undermine the fragile truce. One online video, which garnered millions of views across those platforms and TikTok, claims to show panicked American shoppers snapping up Chinese-branded television sets in the aftermath of trade tensions. That was old footage from 2018 showing Black Friday shopping frenzy at a US supermarket. The falsehood was further amplified by Chinese state media outlets, including China Daily. Other unfounded claims emerged on Chinese platforms about Americans flying to China to shop for Chinese goods, and that US citizens – reeling from the economic fallout of the trade war – were queuing up to purchase supplies in bulk. Professor Andrew Mertha, director of the SAIS China Global Research Centre at the Johns Hopkins University School of Advanced International Studies (SAIS), said these narratives are almost certainly curated by the state. Under the May 12 truce, the US agreed to temporarily reduce the tariff on Chinese imports to 30 per cent from 145 per cent, while China said it would lower its import duty on American goods to 10 per cent from 125 per cent. In April, disinformation security firm Cyabra uncovered an anti-US influence campaign on the Elon Musk-owned X involving thousands of fake or bot-operated accounts. They also targeted global brands such as Gucci, Chanel and Amazon. The accounts blamed Mr Trump’s trade policies for enabling such deceptive marketing practices, while urging consumers to ditch those brands and purchase products directly from China. Mr Dan Brahmy, chief executive of Cyabra, said a third of the accounts weren’t real, but the backlash they triggered was. In April, AFP also uncovered viral TikTok videos by Chinese content creators promoting the spurious claim that international luxury brands were secretly manufacturing their products in China. Prof Mertha from Johns Hopkins University said these narratives will continue and will evolve in parallel with strengthening the Chinese government’s negotiating position.

title: The problem with US foreign policy is the overshooting
content: The test of intelligent analysis of American foreign policy under President Donald Trump is the ability to hold two opposed ideas in the mind at the same time and still retain the ability to function.
resumen:
The test of intelligent analysis of American foreign policy under President Donald Trump is the ability to hold two opposed ideas in the mind at the same time and still retain the ability to function. The first idea is that Trump, on the whole, is a disaster for America’s long-term stature in the international system, making the world less orderly and more chaotic. The second is that Trump, like a broken clock that’s right twice a day, occasionally has the right instinct.

Trump, during his visit to the Middle East, came out with a devastatingly perceptive critique of his predecessors, and in particular the previous Republican president, George W. Bush. Trump said that the “gleaming marvels” of Arabia did “not come from Western interventionists … giving you lectures on how to live.” Those “so-called ‘nation-builders,’ ‘neo-cons,’ or ‘liberal non-profits,’” instead “wrecked far more nations than they built.” They were, Trump said with what sounded like intellectual humility, “intervening in complex societies that they did not even understand themselves.”

Bush, during his second inaugural address in 2005, said: “The survival of liberty in our land increasingly depends on the success of liberty in other lands.” He was equating national with global interests and setting up democracy as the universal standard. “America’s vital interests and our deepest beliefs are now one,” Bush went on, denying the inherent tension between realism and idealism. He then warned despots everywhere that America, “with the ultimate goal of ending tyranny in our world,” will “persistently clarify the choice before every ruler” between “oppression, which is always wrong, and freedom, which is eternally right.”

The U.S. launched a war in Iraq and what would turn into a two-decade quagmire in Afghanistan. The blowback played a large part in defining America’s current political spectrum. At one extreme is the neo-isolationist MAGA wing of the Grand Old Party as embodied by Vice President JD Vance. In the more cerebral middle are centrist Democrats such as Jim Himes.

The passage in Trump’s speech does not reflect his statecraft. Trump was not visiting the region to end the conflict between Israelis and Palestinians, nor was he preparing an extrication of American troops and treasure from the region in the long term. Instead, he dropped in to feed his monarchical fantasies and to collect disconnected favors and deals. This is problem number one: Trump thinks in real-estate rather than geopolitical terms, confusing transactions with relationships, institutions and norms.

Trump consistently bullies America’s closest allies, such as Canada and Denmark, while rhetorically elevating its adversaries, above all Russia. He and Vance do pry in the politics of, say, Germany or South Africa.

This is morally as well as strategically suspect. Germany and South Africa are democracies that overcame dark pasts.

That brings us to problem number two: Whereas Bush was wrong (and hypocritical) to pretend that America’s interests and ideals were indivisible, Trump errs in pretending that values don’t matter. For example, U.S. intelligence services concluded that bin Salman, his host in Riyadh, “approved” the gruesome killing and dismemberment of a Saudi journalist in Istanbul in 2018.

The subtle interplay of interests and values shows up not only in America’s diplomatic relationships but also in its treatment of norms and institutions. They include international law, as well as the many looser “rules” that govern international relations. They also encompass multilateral bodies such as the United Nations, NATO or the World Trade Organization, all of which the U.S. once midwifed because it wanted a more peaceful and prosperous world, but which Trump now derogates and undermines.

This points to problem number three: Trump claims to act solely in America’s national interests and then defines those interests myopically.

Trump, Vance and others in the administration have fallen for the false dichotomy that a Republican foreign policy based on “strength” must either hew to Bush’s otherworldly idealism and zealotry or to a crude isolationism that in practice deteriorates into cynical deal-making.

title: Ahead of ASEAN Summit, Malaysian FM Calls for Regional Action on US Tariffs
content: Along with the conflict in Myanmar, the issue of trade is likely to be high on the agenda at the 46th ASEAN Summit in Kuala Lumpur.
resumen:
Malaysia’s foreign minister has called on Southeast Asian nations to deepen regional economic integration and present a united front in their attempts to address the current global trade uncertainties resulting from sweeping U.S. tariffs.

Mohamad Hasan said that the bloc’s member states were among the nations “most heavily affected” by the “reciprocal” tariffs announced by President Donald Trump last month.

President Donald Trump’s “liberation day” tariff announcement on April 2, Southeast Asian nations were slapped with rates ranging from 17 percent (the Philippines) to 49 percent (Cambodia).

Several nations, including Vietnam and Thailand, have already begun negotiations with the Trump administration over a possible reduction of the tariffs.

The tariffs are likely to be high on the agenda during today’s 46th ASEAN Summit in Kuala Lumpur.

ASEAN leaders are set to express “deep concern” over the Trump administration’s tariff policy at today’s 46th ASEAN Summit.

ASEAN will reaffirm its “collective commitment to a rules-based, open, inclusive, transparent, and non-discriminatory multilateral trading system,” with the World Trade Organization at its core.

Malaysia, the current ASEAN chair, has vowed to shepherd the creation of a united regional response to the Trump tariffs.

Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim said that his government “will lead efforts to present a united regional front, maintain open and resilient supply chains, and ensure ASEAN’s collective voice is heard clearly and firmly on the international stage.”

On April 10, Malaysia chaired a meeting of ASEAN economic ministers that affirmed the bloc’s support for “maintaining a predictable, transparent, non-discriminatory, fair, inclusive, and open regional economic environment which has underpinned growth in regional trade and development.”

Anwar called on ASEAN to “rely more on itself.” He said, “This means strengthening intra-ASEAN trade. We must move beyond rhetoric to execution.”

Mohamad said that Malaysia has requested the convening of a special summit with the U.S. in order to discuss tariffs and said that it was hopeful that this could happen later this year.

Intra-bloc trade made up just 21 percent of the ASEAN total in 2024.

In 2024, China accounted for 20 percent of regional trade, with heavy ASEAN imports. The U.S. followed with 12 percent, made up mostly of exports from ASEAN member states. The European Union made up 8 percent, while trade with the six GCC members made up around 3.5 percent.

ASEAN has concluded negotiations on upgrading the ASEAN Trade in Goods Agreement, first signed in 2010, and the China-ASEAN Free Trade Area, which was agreed in 2002.

The enhanced deals are expected to be signed in October.

Malaysia’s Investment, Trade, and Industry Minister Tengku Zafrul Aziz said, “We remain confident that these milestones will serve as a pivotal enabler for ASEAN’s sustained growth and competitiveness.”

Tengku Zafrul warned the bloc against inaction as it seeks “to navigate an increasingly volatile global economic landscape.”

“ASEAN would need to break away from a business-as-usual approach,” Tengku Zafrul added. “We need to adopt bolder, more agile and more forward-looking strategies. We need to safeguard and advance ASEAN socioeconomic interests.”

Tengku Zafrul said every ASEAN member is a “sovereign nation” and should be supported in pursuing bilateral tariff negotiations with Washington.

Today’s ASEAN Summit will be followed by the second summit between ASEAN and the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC), which comprises Bahrain, Kuwait, Oman, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, and the United Arab Emirates. This will then be followed by the first-ever meeting between ASEAN, China, and the GCC.

title: Interview: Economic Decline & the Death of the American Empire – A Reckoning with Global Realities
content: Death of the American Empire. Einar Tangen analyzes Trump’s trade war collapse, America’s economic decline, and the Global South’s rise. Discover the end of the American empire.
resumen:
In an interview with Professor Glenn Diesen, Einar Tangen, a senior fellow at the Taihe Institute and chairman of Asia Narratives, discusses the U.S. economic strategy under President Donald Trump's trade war and its implications for America’s global dominance. Trump’s tariffs, briefly imposed on nearly every nation before being paused or reversed, were declared a victory despite achieving little. Tangen argues that this erratic approach, coupled with a $38 trillion debt and domestic economic woes, signals the decline of the American empire.

Trump’s tariffs, targeting 180 countries, including allies like Canada and adversaries like China, were a reckless “broadside” lacking an endgame. China refused to negotiate under pressure. The 90-day reset, with talks now in Geneva at the World Trade Organization (WTO), reflects China’s strategic push for neutral ground and multilateral order, contrasting Trump’s unilateral bullying.

The tariffs were based on flawed logic, targeting trade deficits without addressing their root cause: a strong U.S. dollar and domestic policy failures. Importers, not foreign exporters, bear tariff costs, passing them to U.S. consumers, who face rising prices. 70% of Americans live paycheck to paycheck. China’s proposed “Phase Two” deal—reviving a failed Phase One agreement for U.S. agricultural and energy purchases—aims to lock Trump into a transactional pact, ensuring stability until his term ends.

America’s economic woes are traced to a strong dollar, which fuels cheap imports but stifles exports, and a failure to reinvest corporate profits into workers or infrastructure. Since 2001, U.S. corporations reaped trillions by outsourcing to low-wage countries like India ($3/day labor) and China ($20/day), but wages stagnated, shrinking the middle class from 61% in 1971 to 40% today. The U.S.’s $38 trillion debt is a “debt bomb,” with $2 trillion borrowed annually to cover a $1 trillion interest bill. Credit downgrades by S&P (2011), Fitch (2023), and Moody’s (2025) signal eroding confidence, raising borrowing costs. Trump’s $4 trillion unfunded tax cut exacerbates the crisis.

Trump’s push to re-industrialize America is futile. U.S. labor costs cannot compete, especially with only 40% of Americans reading above a sixth-grade level. The Manufacturers Association’s reported 100,000 job vacancies underscore this skills gap. Trump’s dismantling of the Department of Education and failure to invest in STEM further undermines competitiveness. Tariffs raise costs for components in supply chains, making American products like cars less competitive. Recent layoffs, such as FedEx’s 20,000 job cuts, signal broader economic strain.

China plays the “adult in the room,” avoiding confrontation to preserve global stability. Beijing seeks a Phase Two deal to manage Trump’s volatility. China diversifies, redirecting exports to Europe, Southeast Asia, and Latin America, and strengthening BRICS institutions like the New Development Bank. Initiatives like grain corridors and commodity exchanges with Russia reduce reliance on U.S.-dominated systems.

The U.S.’s unreliability has alienated allies. Canada’s election of a nationalist leader and Europe’s hesitation signal a global pivot away from U.S. hegemony. Tangen sees BRICS nations—China, Russia, Brazil—as inheritors of a broken Western-led order, tasked with stabilizing global trade and finance.

America’s isolation is self-inflicted, driven by Trump’s rejection of international norms. Its $38 trillion debt, coupled with a shrinking middle class and educational deficits, portends collapse. Tangen warns of a potential military escalation as Trump’s last card to unify a fracturing nation, risking global catastrophe. The bond market’s looming hammer—higher interest rates—could trigger bankruptcy. Tangen sees no easy fix.

Einar Tangen’s analysis paints a dire portrait of America’s economic decline, accelerated by Trump’s incoherent trade war and systemic failures. China’s strategic patience and global diversification contrast with the U.S.’s isolation, signaling the death of its empire. The Global South, led by BRICS, emerges as a stabilizing force.

title: ASEAN leaders to show concern over U.S. tariffs, Myanmar
content: Leaders of the Association of Southeast Asia Nations are set to show their deep concern over "unilateral tariff measures" without mentioning the United States at their meeting in Malaysia on Monday, ...
resumen:
Southeast Asian leaders held a summit in Kuala Lumpur on Monday under the shadow of sweeping new U.S. tariffs. Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim expressed concern over "increasingly complex and sobering global developments."

Anwar, whose country currently chairs the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, said at the meeting's outset that the global trading system is "under further strain, with the recent imposition of U.S. unilateral tariffs," with the duties ranging from 10 percent to 49 percent to hit the regional grouping's 10 members.

ASEAN has displayed resilience amid "increasingly complex and sobering global developments," he said.

Anwar said he had written to U.S. President Donald Trump to propose an ASEAN-U.S. meeting.

According to a draft of the summit chairman's statement obtained by Kyodo News, the leaders showed their deep concern over "unilateral tariff measures" without explicitly mentioning the United States, as their countries, like others, are facing Trump's so-called reciprocal tariffs.

The leaders warned that unilateral tariffs pose "complex and multidimensional challenges to ASEAN's economic growth, stability and integration," reaffirming the regional bloc's commitment to a "nondiscriminatory multilateral trading system, with the World Trade Organization at its core, according to the draft statement.

Following Trump's announcement of the tariffs, ASEAN trade ministers held a special virtual meeting in April and said they would not retaliate.

The ASEAN trade and foreign ministers met separately on Sunday in the Malaysian capital.

Besides tariffs, the ongoing civil war in Myanmar, following a coup in February 2021 that ousted the elected government led by Aung San Suu Kyi, was on the summit agenda, according to the draft.

Anwar said at Monday's summit that ASEAN has been able to take "positive steps" within an informal advisory group that he launched by requesting former Thai Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra to serve as an adviser.

Further humanitarian assistance for Myanmar, the central region of which was hit by an earthquake on March 28 that killed over 3,700 people, was stressed, according to the draft statement, including a call by the leaders for greater international financial support.

From Myanmar, Aung Kyaw Moe, permanent secretary of its Foreign Ministry, participated in the summit as ASEAN has only allowed attendance by a nonpolitical representative from the country since October 2021, effectively excluding the junta chief.

Other issues discussed included East Timor's accession to ASEAN. The leaders agreed the country, currently an observer, will gain full membership in October, Milena Rangel, vice minister for ASEAN affairs of East Timor's foreign ministry, told reporters after the summit.

ASEAN groups Brunei, Cambodia, Indonesia, Laos, Malaysia, Myanmar, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand and Vietnam.

title: EU readying apt response to US tariffs
content: On Friday, US President Donald Trump threatened to impose a 50 percent tariff on EU imports starting from June 1, saying negotiations with the trading bloc of 27 nations "are going nowhere".
resumen:
Mutual trust between the European Union and the United States has been "severely undermined" by the recent tariff dispute, and the outlook for relations remains fraught, despite claims of a soothing of tensions over the weekend.

US President Donald Trump threatened to impose a 50 percent tariff on EU imports starting from June 1, saying negotiations with the trading bloc of 27 nations "are going nowhere".

He spoke with European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen, which resulted in any possible tariffs being delayed until July.

Zhang Haiyan, a professor specializing in international trade at the Hangzhou, Zhejiang province-based Zhejiang Financial College, has warned that the European perception that it had been "betrayed by its ally" meant it was ready to punch back if necessary.

The EU's preparations and countermeasures for the latest US tariff policy move will be more thorough and comprehensive than in previous trade conflicts, enabling it to retaliate if negotiations fail in the following days.

The EU has previously threatened to hit the US back with tariffs of its own, including a list of US exports viewed as possible targets, including cars and aircraft.

It has also long been wary of the activities and market dominance of major US-based tech firms, which could potentially be an area for it to target if trade tensions are ramped up further.

Beyond the digital sector, financial services provided by US banks within the EU are also seen as likely candidates for countermeasures.

Trump said "let's be honest, the EU was formed in order to screw the US …that's the purpose of it, and they've done a good job of it".

Lars Klingbeil, finance minister in Germany's newly-formed government, has said that "serious negotiations" with Washington are needed, rather than "further provocations", and that he has spoken to his US counterpart Scott Bessent about the issue.

Oliver Oehms, executive director and board member of the German Chamber of Commerce in China-North China, said that the ongoing lack of certainty about what would happen next would inevitably cause anxiety, which could have global consequences.

Zak Stambor, an analyst at eMarketer Inc, a New York City-based market research company, said that "ever-shifting trade policies" meant "navigating an increasingly unpredictable landscape", making life and any attempts at financial planning harder for manufacturers and consumers.

title: Trump threatens Apple with 25% tariff: Is now a good time to buy an iPhone?
content: In addition to promising a 50% tariff on the European Union, unless E.U. leaders come to an agreement with the Trump administration within approximately nine days, the president threatened Apple with ...
resumen:
President Donald Trump threatened Apple with 25% tariffs on any iPhone sold, and not made, in the U.S.

Trump posted on Truth Social, his social-media platform, on Friday: "I have long ago informed Tim Cook of Apple (AAPL) that I expect their iPhone's [sic] that will be sold in the United States of America will be manufactured and built in the United States, not India, or anyplace else."

Ming-Chi Kuo, TF International Securities analyst, said the costs would likely make such a move prohibitive.

Prices for the iPhone product line start at $799 and go as high as $1,599 for the iPhone 16 Pro Max.

The iPhone 16 is powered by an "A18 Bionic" chip, integrates artificial intelligence into its camera control and has 85% recycled content.

Alex Kidman, who writes Alex Reviews Tech, said the iPhone 16's 60Hz screen at this price is "indefensible," and cited "inconsistent battery life and overly hot Qi2 charging." (60Hz means the screen updates 60 times every second.).

Some 36% of iPhone buyers in the 12 months ending December 2024 reported having their previous phone for two years or less, compared with 31% in the prior year.

The household savings rate in the U.S. fell to 3.9% in March from 4.1% in February. It averaged 8.4% from 1959 until 2025, reaching an all-time high of 32% in April 2020 and a record low of 1% in July 2005, according to Trading Economics.

Andrzej Skiba, head of U.S. fixed income at RBC Global Asset Management, said the environment surrounding Trump's trade approach may also ensure that borrowing costs remain elevated. "The Fed," he said, "won't likely be able to cut rates in this environment."

title: Los mercados europeos registran ganancias tras el aplazamiento de aranceles por Trump
content: Los mercados europeos concluyeron en alza tras el anuncio de Trump, quien postergó un arancel del 50% sobre la UE hasta el 9 de julio. Inversionistas se mostraron optimistas ante la posibilidad de acu ...
resumen:
Los mercados europeos concluyeron en alza tras el anuncio de Trump, quien postergó un arancel del 50% sobre la UE hasta el 9 de julio. Inversionistas se mostraron optimistas ante la posibilidad de acuerdos comerciales.

Las acciones en los mercados europeos cerraron positivamente el lunes, mientras que los futuros de Estados Unidos se dispararon después de que el presidente Donald Trump anunciara la postergación de la implementación de un arancel del 50% sobre productos de la Unión Europea hasta el 9 de julio.

Trump hizo este anuncio tras una conversación telefónica con Ursula von der Leyen, presidenta de la Comisión Europea, quien manifestó su interés en entablar negociaciones serias para alcanzar un acuerdo comercial.

El principal negociador comercial de la UE destacó que sostuvo "buenas llamadas" con funcionarios del gobierno de Trump y reafirmó el compromiso de la UE de alcanzar un trato antes de la fecha límite del 9 de julio.

El futuro del S&P 500 se incrementó un 1,3% y el del promedio industrial Dow Jones avanzó un 1%. Asimismo, el futuro del compuesto Nasdaq subió un 1,4%.

El DAX de Alemania subió un 1,5% hasta alcanzar los 23.977,83 puntos, mientras que el CAC 40 de París ganó un 1% y se situó en 7.810,49 enteros.

En Asia, el Nikkei 225 de Tokio se elevó un 1% hasta cerrar en 37.531,53 unidades, y el KOSPI de Seúl aumentó un 2%, logrando los 2.644,40 puntos.

El Hang Seng de Hong Kong, descendió un 1,4% hasta 23.282,33 unidades y el índice compuesto de Shanghái, que cayó un 0,1% a 3.346,84 enteros.

El S&P/ASX 200 de Australia experimentó cambios marginales y se mantuvo en 8.361,00 puntos. En contraste, el Taiex de Taiwán se redujo un 0,5%, mientras que el Sensex de India avanzó un 0,5%.

En Estados Unidos, los precios de las acciones sufrieron una caída el viernes pasado. El S&P 500 había perdido un 0,7%.

De acuerdo a Trump, los aranceles sobre teléfonos inteligentes fabricados en el extranjero podrían implementarse a finales de junio.

A medida que se aproximan las negociaciones comerciales, los inversionistas estarán atentos a los desarrollos que podrían influir en los mercados en las semanas venideras.

title: Trump’s Tariffs and Tax Bill May Derail U.S. Battery Industry
content: Domestic factories that make batteries to store power to meet America’s rising energy demand depend on Chinese components and federal subsidies.
resumen: The batteries produced at an LG Energy Solution factory in Holland, Mich., will store power to balance supply and demand on U.S. electric grids. The silver-colored pouches, roughly the size of two computer keyboards set end to end, will be placed into large battery containers that can be more than 20 feet wide. Electric utilities and other energy companies have begun spending billions of dollars to install scores of such big batteries around the country. The batteries play an increasingly central role in the electricity business, especially in states like California and Texas. President Trump’s tariffs on China may knock this fledgling industry off course. House Republicans, with Mr. Trump’s blessing, have passed a budget bill that analysts say would drastically restrict access to subsidies for making and using rechargeable batteries. Tristan Doherty, chief product officer for LG Energy Solution’s U.S. energy storage unit, Vertech, compared tariffs to a drug that can be deadly at high concentrations. What happens to the companies that make batteries and install them on American grids will affect how quickly the country is able to meet rising power demand and how much that energy will cost. Mr. Trump’s tariffs on China have already caused battery costs to rise sharply for U.S. buyers. When U.S. tariffs on Chinese batteries topped 150 percent for a monthlong period starting in April, companies stopped importing cells from China. LG has made batteries for vehicles at its Michigan factory for more than a decade. At the beginning of May, the plant also began making batteries typically used to store energy. The storage batteries use iron and phosphate and go by the name LFP. China makes nearly all LFP batteries. Most U.S. electric cars, by contrast, use batteries made up of materials like nickel and cobalt. The Trump administration temporarily lowered tariffs on China in mid-May, to 30 percent, though batteries face additional levies. The legislation that Republicans advanced would also make it harder to claim lucrative subsidies for making and installing batteries. If the Republican budget bill took effect in its current form, it would be “something of a kill switch” for the tax credits available for making batteries, said Antoine Vagneur-Jones, an analyst at BloombergNEF. It also would quickly end tax credits for installing them on the grid. Tesla warned in April that the levies would have an “outsized” effect on its energy business, which relies on Chinese batteries. Fluence Energy, a company in Arlington, Va., lowered its annual revenue forecast by around 20 percent, saying it was delaying projects and putting off new contracts because of unpredictable U.S. trade policy. John Zahurancik, the company’s president of the Americas, said it’s the uncertainty around where the price will be that is the issue. Chris Wright, the energy secretary, seemed ambivalent about them in a March interview with The New York Times. The Trump administration did not directly address batteries but criticized wind and solar energy. The science behind LFP batteries was developed in the 1990s by researchers at the University of Texas at Austin. But it was China that recognized the technology’s commercial promise. Most manufacturers in the United States make batteries with nickel and cobalt. Arumugam Manthiram, a University of Texas engineering professor whose research helped pave the way for LFP batteries, said that for a long time, the U.S. was not paying too much attention. A123 Systems briefly produced LFP batteries in the United States, only to file for bankruptcy protection in 2012. A Chinese automotive supplier eventually bought most of the company’s assets. LG Energy Solution, one of the world’s biggest battery manufacturers, began making cells for cars in Holland. LG had planned to expand the factory to supply Toyota’s vehicles. The company changed its expansion plan and outfitted a new wing of the factory for LFP production, a $1.4 billion undertaking. When the new assembly lines are running at full tilt, they will make enough cells to satisfy more than a quarter of current U.S. demand for LFP batteries, according to data from LG and Benchmark Mineral Intelligence. The investment decision predated Mr. Trump’s trade policy announcements, Mr. Doherty said. Another company, AESC, also started making LFP batteries for storage systems this spring, in Tennessee. LG expects that its cells from Holland will not have any Chinese ingredients by early 2026, Mr. Doherty said. Without tax credits, it would not be profitable for LG to make cells in the United States at current battery prices, Mr. Doherty said.

title: China, EU and ASEAN should 'deepen' trade ties
content: In the face of persistent trade tensions with the United States, China and other economies should deepen regional economic cooperation and defend the multilateral trade system, said a senior trade ...
resumen: In the face of persistent trade tensions with the United States, China and other economies should deepen regional economic cooperation and defend the multilateral trade system, said Zhao Zhongxiu, president of the University of International Business and Economics in Beijing. Washington's current economic policies, featuring sweeping tariff hikes, represent a unilateral attempt to rewrite global trade rules to its own advantage. These developments have made it more urgent for major economies — such as the European Union, the Association of Southeast Asian Nations and China — to strengthen consensus and deepen cooperation, thereby jointly improving agility and resilience of regional and international supply chains. The so-called reciprocal tariffs have raised the average US tariff rate to nearly 30 percent. That marks a historic regression, undermining the WTO framework that took decades to build. Global tariff negotiations since 1947 have lowered duties in developed economies to 3 to 5 percent. If unchecked, the US policy reversal may trigger retaliatory cycles, pushing the world into a "jungle economy", jeopardizing 86 percent of global trade that relies on free trade rules. Since the US announced the so-called liberation-day tariffs package, China's firm stance and calibrated countermeasures have helped bring Washington back to the negotiation table. On May 12, the two countries announced a series of tariff adjustments aimed at easing trade tensions. Effective US tariffs on Chinese products remain around 50 percent, far higher than pre-2018 levels, according to Zhao. Shared pressure from US tariff measures is pushing China and the EU closer. Coordination between the two is no longer optional — it's imperative. This is a critical window of opportunity for the two sides to deepen cooperation and strengthen economic ties. By leveraging shared interests, the two sides can push back protectionist disruptions and reinforce the multilateral trade system. China-EU collaboration could start with "small yet practical initiatives", and gradually elevate strategic dialogue to higher levels to advance broader partnership. China's commitment to green development resonates with the EU's decarbonization efforts, creating opportunity to jointly transform the EU's Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM) — currently a unilateral carbon pricing instrument — into a multilateral framework consistent with WTO rules and global climate responses. China and the EU share common priorities — including digital trade facilitation, standards development and consumer protections. Deeper collaboration on emerging issues such as aligning standards in 6G networks could position China and the EU as key pillars stabilizing the multilateral digital trade system in the future, in contrast to the US' "lackluster engagement" in multilateral e-commerce initiatives. Consensus on rules regarding green or digital economy isn't just about economic gains — it's about defending a fair and rules-based multilateral system. Resolving lingering disputes, such as the EU's tariffs on Chinese electric vehicles, is also essential for building mutual trust. China and ASEAN are strengthening industrial chain integration under the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership, particularly by leveraging rules of origin to reshape regional supply chains. ASEAN can serve as a 'stabilizer' for China's economic growth amid US tariff pressures. By relocating production to ASEAN-based industrial parks, Chinese companies can supply to both local and international markets, with or without access to the US market. For ASEAN, investments from Chinese companies support local industrialization, job creation, and tax revenues. It's win-win — as long as China is avoiding domestic industrial hollowing-out. China's ability to respond to US unilateralism and hegemony stems from its supply chain resilience, and its capacity to withstand inventory adjustment cycles. China seeks a full removal of unjustified US tariffs linked to the so-called fentanyl issue. Domestic pressures in the US — ranging from public discontent over supply shortages, rising costs, to broader supply chain disruptions — have pushed US negotiators to adopt a more pragmatic stance. Despite the current tariff truce, the US could reinstate suspended tariffs or attach new conditions. Washington's habitual use of the so-called 'art of the deal' risks derailing progress with unreasonable and excessive demands. The future of China-US tariff disputes remains highly uncertain. Ultimately, it is a matter of endurance. China has prioritized self-reliance in sci-tech innovation and domestic market expansion, and its new growth drivers have begun to yield results. China's value-added industrial output grew by 6.1 percent on a yearly basis in April. The manufacturing sector's value-added output increased by 6.6 percent year-on-year, with that of equipment manufacturing and high-tech manufacturing up by 9.8 percent and 10 percent, respectively.

title: Trump's tariffs launched global trade wars a timeline of how we got here
content: Volley after volley of new tariffs from US President Donald Trump have plunged the country into trade wars abroad, creating uncertainty for businesses and households. Trump is no stranger to ...
resumen:
Volley after volley of new tariffs from US President Donald Trump have plunged the country into trade wars abroad, creating uncertainty for businesses and households.

Trump launched a trade war during his first term as well, taking particular aim at China by putting taxes on most of its goods. Beijing responded with its own retaliatory tariffs on a range of US products. Trump also used the threat of more tariffs to force Canada and Mexico to renegotiate a North American trade pact.

Economists stress there are greater consequences on businesses and economies worldwide under Trump's more sweeping tariffs this time around — and that higher prices leave consumers footing the bill.

January 20: Trump is sworn into office. In his inaugural address, he promises to “tariff and tax foreign countries to enrich our citizens." He reiterates plans to create an agency called the External Revenue Service. On his first day in office, Trump says he expects to put 25 per cent tariffs on Canada and Mexico starting on February 1, while declining to immediately flesh out plans for taxing Chinese imports.

January 26: Trump threatens 25 per cent tariffs on all Colombia imports and other retaliatory measures after President Gustavo Petro's rejects two US military aircraft carrying migrants to the country. Petro announces a retaliatory 25 per cent increase in Colombian tariffs on US goods. Colombia later reversed its decision and accepted the flights carrying migrants. The two countries soon signalled a halt in the trade dispute.

February 1: Trump signs an executive order to impose tariffs on imports from Mexico, Canada and China — 10 per cent on all imports from China and 25 per cent on imports from Mexico and Canada starting February 4. Trump invoked this power by declaring a national emergency. The action prompts swift outrage from all three countries, with promises of retaliatory measures.

February 3: Trump agrees to a 30-day pause on his tariff threats against Mexico and Canada.

February 4: Trump's new 10 per cent tariffs on all Chinese imports to the US still go into effect. China retaliates the same day by announcing a flurry of countermeasures, including new duties on a variety of American goods and an anti-monopoly investigation into Google. China's 15 per cent tariffs on coal and liquefied natural gas products, and a 10 per cent levy on crude oil, agricultural machinery and large-engine cars imported from the US, take effect February 10.

February 10: Trump announces plans to hike steel and aluminum tariffs starting March 12. He removes the exemptions from his 2018 tariffs on steel, meaning that all steel imports will be taxed at a minimum of 25 per cent, and also raises his 2018 aluminum tariffs from 10 per cent to 25 per cent.

February 13: Trump announces a plan for “reciprocal” tariffs — promising to increase US tariffs to match the tax rates that countries worldwide charge on imports.

March 4: Trump's 25 per cent tariffs on imports from Canada and Mexico go into effect, though he limits the levy to 10 per cent on Canadian energy. He also doubles the tariff on all Chinese imports to 20 per cent. All three countries promise retaliatory measures. Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announces tariffs on more than USD 100 billion of American goods over the course of 21 days. Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum says her country would respond with its own retaliatory tariffs on US goods. China imposes tariffs of up to 15 per cent on a wide array of key US farm exports, set to take effect March 10. It also expands the number of US companies subject to export controls and other restrictions by about two dozen.

March 5: Trump grants a one-month exemption on his new tariffs impacting goods from Mexico and Canada for US automakers.

March 6: Trump postpones 25 per cent tariffs on many imports from Mexico and some imports from Canada for a month.

March 10: China's retaliatory 15 per cent tariffs on key American farm products — including chicken, pork, soybeans and beef — take effect.

March 12: Trump's new tariffs on all steel and aluminum imports go into effect. Both metals are now taxed at 25 per cent across the board. The European Union takes retaliatory trade action promising new duties on US industrial and farm products. The measures will cover goods from the United States worth some 26 billion euros (USD 28 billion). Canada announces plans to impose more retaliatory tariffs worth CAD 29.8 billion (USD 20.7 billion) on US imports, set to go into effect March 13.

March 13: Trump threatens a 200 per cent tariff on European wine, Champagne and spirits if the European Union goes forward with its previously-announced plans for a 50 per cent tariff on American whiskey.

March 24: Trump says he will place a 25 per cent tariff on all imports from any country that buys oil or gas from Venezuela, in addition to imposing new tariffs on the South American country itself, starting April 2.

March 26: Trump says he is placing 25 per cent tariffs on auto imports. These auto imports will start being collected April 3 — beginning with taxes on fully-imported cars. The tariffs are set to then expand to applicable auto parts in the following weeks, through May 3.

April 2: Trump announces his long-promised “reciprocal” tariffs — declaring a 10 per cent baseline tax on imports across the board starting April 5, as well as higher rates for dozens of nations that run trade surpluses with the US to take effect April 9. Among those steeper levies, Trump says the US will now charge a 34 per cent tax on imports from China, a 20 per cent tax on imports from the European Union, 25 per cent on South Korea, 24 per cent on Japan and 32 per cent on Taiwan. The new tariffs come on top of previously-imposed levies, including the 20 per cent tax Trump announced on all Chinese imports earlier this year.

April 3: Trump's previously-announced auto tariffs begin. Prime Minister Mark Carney says that Canada will match the 25 per cent levies with a tariff on vehicles imported from the US.

April 4: China announces plans to impose a 34 per cent tariff on imports of all US products beginning April 10, matching Trump's new "reciprocal” tariff on Chinese goods, as part of a flurry of retaliatory measures. The Commerce Ministry in Beijing says it will also impose more export controls on rare earths.

April 5: Trump's 10 per cent minimum tariff on nearly all countries and territories takes effect.

April 9: Trump's higher “reciprocal” rates go into effect. But hours later, his administration says it will suspend most of these higher rates for 90 days, while maintaining the recently-imposed 10 per cent levy on nearly all global imports. China is the exception. After following through on a threat to raise levies against China
